<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Canada</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>

<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in North America</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Canada_(disambiguation)" title="Canada (disambiguation)">Canada (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1073938472">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Canada&amp;params=60_N_110_W_region:CA"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">60°N</span> <span class="longitude">110°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">60°N 110°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">60; -110</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>
</p>

<div style="padding-bottom:3px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg" title="Coat of arms of Canada"><img alt="At the top there is a rendition of St. Edward's Crown, with the crest of a crowned gold lion standing on a twisted wreath of red and white silk and holding a maple leaf in its right paw underneath. The lion is standing on top of a helm, which is above the escutcheon, ribbon, motto, and compartment. There is a supporter on either side of the escutcheon and ribbon; an English lion on the left and a Scottish unicorn on the right." data-file-height="200" data-file-width="149" decoding="async" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg/85px-Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg/128px-Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg/170px-Coat_of_arms_of_Canada.svg.png 2x" width="85"/></a></div>

<p><b>Canada</b> is a country in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>. Its <a href="/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada" title="Provinces and territories of Canada">ten provinces and three territories</a> extend from the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> and northward into the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Ocean" title="Arctic Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a>, covering over 9.98 million square kilometres (3.85 million square miles), making it the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">second-largest country by total area</a>. Its southern and western <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Canada–United States border">border with the United States</a>, stretching 8,891 kilometres (5,525 mi), is the world's longest binational land border. Canada's capital is <a href="/wiki/Ottawa" title="Ottawa">Ottawa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_census_metropolitan_areas_and_agglomerations_in_Canada" title="List of census metropolitan areas and agglomerations in Canada">its three largest metropolitan areas</a> are <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montreal" title="Montreal">Montreal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vancouver" title="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Canada" title="Indigenous peoples in Canada">Indigenous peoples</a> have continuously inhabited what is now Canada for thousands of years. Beginning in the 16th century, <a href="/wiki/British_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="British colonization of the Americas">British</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="French colonization of the Americas">French</a> expeditions explored and later settled along the Atlantic coast. As a consequence of <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Canada" title="Military history of Canada">various armed conflicts</a>, France <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1763)" title="Treaty of Paris (1763)">ceded nearly all</a> of <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">its colonies in North America</a> in 1763. In 1867, with the union of three <a href="/wiki/British_North_America" title="British North America">British North American</a> colonies through <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Confederation" title="Canadian Confederation">Confederation</a>, Canada was formed as a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">dominion</a> of four provinces. This began an <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Canada" title="Territorial evolution of Canada">accretion of provinces and territories</a> and a process of increasing autonomy from the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>. This widening autonomy was highlighted by the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931" title="Statute of Westminster 1931">Statute of Westminster 1931</a> and culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Canada_Act_1982" title="Canada Act 1982">Canada Act 1982</a>, which severed the vestiges of legal dependence on the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">Parliament of the United Kingdom</a>.
</p><p>Canada is a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary democracy</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster tradition</a>. The country's <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada" title="Prime Minister of Canada">prime minister</a>—who holds office by virtue of their ability to <a href="/wiki/Confidence_and_supply" title="Confidence and supply">command the confidence</a> of the elected <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_Canada" title="House of Commons of Canada">House of Commons</a>—and is appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Governor_General_of_Canada" title="Governor General of Canada">governor general</a>, representing the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Canada" title="Monarchy of Canada">monarch</a>, who serves as <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>. The country is a <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">Commonwealth realm</a> and is <a href="/wiki/Official_bilingualism_in_Canada" title="Official bilingualism in Canada">officially bilingual (English and French)</a> at the federal level. It <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_Canada" title="International rankings of Canada">ranks among the highest</a> in international measurements of government transparency, civil liberties, quality of life, economic freedom, education, gender equality and environmental sustainability. It is one of the world's most ethnically diverse and <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_Canada" title="Multiculturalism in Canada">multicultural</a> nations, the product of <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Canada" title="Immigration to Canada">large-scale immigration</a>. Canada's <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Canada–United States relations">long and complex relationship with the United States</a> has had a significant impact on <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Canada" title="Economy of Canada">its economy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Canada" title="Culture of Canada">culture</a>.
</p><p>A highly <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a>, Canada has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">24th highest nominal per capita income globally</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">sixteenth-highest</a> ranking on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. Its advanced economy is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eighth-largest in the world</a>, relying chiefly upon its abundant natural resources and well-developed international trade networks. Canada is part of several major international and intergovernmental institutions or groupings including the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven" title="Group of Seven">G7</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Ten_(economics)" title="Group of Ten (economics)">Group of Ten</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD), the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Council" title="Arctic Council">Arctic Council</a>, the <span title="French-language text"><i lang="fr"><a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a></i></span>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum, and the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Canada" title="Name of Canada">Name of Canada</a></div>
<p>While a variety of theories have been postulated for the etymological origins of <i>Canada</i>, the name is now accepted as coming from the <a href="/wiki/St._Lawrence_Iroquoians" title="St. Lawrence Iroquoians">St. Lawrence Iroquoian</a> word <span title="Laurentian-language text"><i lang="lre">kanata</i></span>, meaning "village" or "settlement".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> In 1535, Indigenous inhabitants of the present-day <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City" title="Quebec City">Quebec City</a> region used the word to direct French explorer <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Cartier" title="Jacques Cartier">Jacques Cartier</a> to the village of <a href="/wiki/Stadacona" title="Stadacona">Stadacona</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rayburn2001_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rayburn2001-11">[11]</a></sup> Cartier later used the word <i>Canada</i> to refer not only to that particular village but to the entire area subject to <a href="/wiki/Donnacona" title="Donnacona">Donnacona</a> (the chief at Stadacona);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rayburn2001_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rayburn2001-11">[11]</a></sup> by 1545, European books and maps had begun referring to this small region along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_River" title="Saint Lawrence River">Saint Lawrence River</a> as <i>Canada</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rayburn2001_11-2"><a href="#cite_note-Rayburn2001-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 16th to the early 18th century, "<a href="/wiki/Canada_(New_France)" title="Canada (New France)">Canada</a>" referred to the part of <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">New France</a> that lay along the Saint Lawrence River.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> In 1791, the area became two British colonies called <a href="/wiki/Upper_Canada" title="Upper Canada">Upper Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_Canada" title="Lower Canada">Lower Canada</a>. These two colonies were collectively named <a href="/wiki/The_Canadas" title="The Canadas">the Canadas</a> until their union as the British <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Canada" title="Province of Canada">Province of Canada</a> in 1841.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Upon <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Confederation" title="Canadian Confederation">Confederation in 1867</a>, <i>Canada</i> was adopted as the legal name for the new country at the <a href="/wiki/London_Conference_of_1866" title="London Conference of 1866">London Conference</a>, and the word <i><a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">Dominion</a></i> was conferred as the country's title.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> By the 1950s, the term <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Canada" title="Dominion of Canada">Dominion of Canada</a> was no longer used by the United Kingdom, which considered Canada a "Realm of the Commonwealth".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morra2016_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Morra2016-15">[15]</a></sup> The government of <a href="/wiki/Louis_St._Laurent" title="Louis St. Laurent">Louis St. Laurent</a> ended the practice of using <i>Dominion</i> in the statutes of Canada in 1951.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McLeanQuentin-Baxter2017_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-McLeanQuentin-Baxter2017-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Canada_Act_1982" title="Canada Act 1982">Canada Act 1982</a>, which brought the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Canada" title="Constitution of Canada">constitution of Canada</a> fully under Canadian control, referred only to <i>Canada</i>. Later that year, the name of the national holiday was changed from Dominion Day to <a href="/wiki/Canada_Day" title="Canada Day">Canada Day</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-buckner_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-19">[19]</a></sup> The term <i>Dominion</i> was used to distinguish the federal government from the provinces, though after the <a href="/wiki/Canada_in_World_War_II" title="Canada in World War II">Second World War</a> the term <i>federal</i> had replaced <i>dominion</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Canada" title="History of Canada">History of Canada</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Canadian_history" title="Timeline of Canadian history">Timeline of Canadian history</a> and <a href="/wiki/Historiography_of_Canada" title="Historiography of Canada">Historiography of Canada</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_peoples">Indigenous peoples</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Langs_N.Amer.svg"><img alt="Colour-coded map of North America showing the distribution of North American language families north of Mexico" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="562" data-file-width="619" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Langs_N.Amer.svg/260px-Langs_N.Amer.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Langs_N.Amer.svg/390px-Langs_N.Amer.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Langs_N.Amer.svg/520px-Langs_N.Amer.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Langs_N.Amer.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Indigenous_languages_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous languages of the Americas">Linguistic areas of North American Indigenous peoples</a> at the time of European contact</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Canada" title="Indigenous peoples in Canada">Indigenous peoples in present-day Canada</a> include the <a href="/wiki/First_Nations_in_Canada" title="First Nations in Canada">First Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Inuit" title="Inuit">Inuit</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C3%A9tis_people_in_Canada" title="Métis people in Canada">Métis</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GraberKuprecht2012_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-GraberKuprecht2012-21">[21]</a></sup> the last being of <a href="/wiki/Mixed-blood" title="Mixed-blood">mixed descent</a> who originated in the mid-17th century when First Nations people married European settlers and subsequently developed their own identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GraberKuprecht2012_21-1"><a href="#cite_note-GraberKuprecht2012-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Settlement_of_the_Americas" title="Settlement of the Americas">first inhabitants of North America</a> are generally hypothesized to have migrated from <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a> by way of the <a href="/wiki/Beringia" title="Beringia">Bering land bridge</a> and arrived at least 14,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FaganDurrani2016_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FaganDurrani2016-23">[23]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paleo-Indian" title="Paleo-Indian">Paleo-Indian</a> archeological sites at <a href="/wiki/Old_Crow_Flats" title="Old Crow Flats">Old Crow Flats</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bluefish_Caves" title="Bluefish Caves">Bluefish Caves</a> are two of the oldest sites of human habitation in Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rawat2012_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rawat2012-24">[24]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_Canada#The_Stone_Age:_Fire_(14,000_BC_–_AD_1600)" title="Technological and industrial history of Canada">characteristics of Indigenous societies</a> included permanent settlements, agriculture, complex societal hierarchies, and trading networks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Some of these cultures had collapsed by the time European explorers arrived in the late 15th and early 16th centuries and have only been discovered through archeological investigations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas">Indigenous population</a> at the time of the first European settlements is estimated to have been between 200,000<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dying_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-dying-28">[28]</a></sup> and two million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steckel_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-Steckel-29">[29]</a></sup> with a figure of 500,000 accepted by Canada's <a href="/wiki/Royal_Commission_on_Aboriginal_Peoples" title="Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples">Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> As a consequence of European colonization, the Indigenous population declined by forty to eighty percent, and several First Nations, such as the <a href="/wiki/Beothuk" title="Beothuk">Beothuk</a>, disappeared.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Marshall1998_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-Marshall1998-31">[31]</a></sup> The decline is attributed to several causes, including the <a href="/wiki/Columbian_exchange" title="Columbian exchange">transfer of European diseases</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Influenza" title="Influenza">influenza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">measles</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> to which they had no natural immunity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dying_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-dying-28">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> conflicts over the fur trade, conflicts with the colonial authorities and settlers, and the loss of Indigenous lands to settlers and the subsequent collapse of several nations' self-sufficiency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LaidlawLester2015_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-LaidlawLester2015-33">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although not without conflict, <a href="/wiki/European_Canadians" title="European Canadians">European Canadians</a>' early interactions with First Nations and Inuit populations were relatively peaceful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> First Nations and Métis peoples played a critical part in the development of <a href="/wiki/Former_colonies_and_territories_in_Canada" title="Former colonies and territories in Canada">European colonies in Canada</a>, particularly for their role in assisting European <a href="/wiki/Coureur_des_bois" title="Coureur des bois">coureur des bois</a> and <a href="/wiki/Voyageurs" title="Voyageurs">voyageurs</a> in their explorations of the continent during the <a href="/wiki/North_American_fur_trade" title="North American fur trade">North American fur trade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Miller2009j_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-Miller2009j-36">[36]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Canadian_Crown_and_Indigenous_peoples_of_Canada" title="The Canadian Crown and Indigenous peoples of Canada">The Crown and Indigenous peoples</a> began interactions <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_European_colonization_of_North_America" title="Timeline of the European colonization of North America">during the European colonization period</a>, though the Inuit, in general, had more limited interaction with European settlers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> From the late 18th century, European Canadians forced Indigenous peoples to assimilate into a western culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> These attempts reached a climax in the late 19th and early 20th centuries with <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Indian_residential_school_system" title="Canadian Indian residential school system">forced integration</a> and <a href="/wiki/High_Arctic_relocation" title="High Arctic relocation">relocations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> A period of redress is underway, which started with the appointment of the <a href="/wiki/Truth_and_Reconciliation_Commission_of_Canada" title="Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada">Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a> in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_colonization">European colonization</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1090" data-file-width="1530" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg/260px-Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg/390px-Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg/520px-Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of territorial claims in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a> by 1750, before the <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a>, which was part of the greater worldwide conflict known as the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a> (1756 to 1763). Possessions of Britain (pink), <a href="/wiki/New_France" title="New France">New France</a> (blue), and Spain (orange, <i>California, Pacific Northwest, and Great Basin not indicated</i>)</div></div></div>
<p>It is believed that the first European to explore the east coast of Canada was <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Norse</a> explorer <a href="/wiki/Leif_Erikson" title="Leif Erikson">Leif Erikson</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JohansenPritzker2007p727_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-JohansenPritzker2007p727-42">[42]</a></sup> In approximately 1000 AD, the Norse built a small short-lived encampment that was occupied sporadically for perhaps 20 years at <a href="/wiki/L%27Anse_aux_Meadows" title="L'Anse aux Meadows">L'Anse aux Meadows</a> on the northern tip of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newfoundland" title="Newfoundland">Newfoundland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CordellLightfoot2008_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-CordellLightfoot2008-43">[43]</a></sup> No further European exploration occurred until 1497, when Italian seafarer <a href="/wiki/John_Cabot" title="John Cabot">John Cabot</a> explored and claimed Canada's <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Canada" title="Atlantic Canada">Atlantic coast</a> in the name of King <a href="/wiki/Henry_VII_of_England" title="Henry VII of England">Henry VII of England</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BlakeKeshen2017p19_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-BlakeKeshen2017p19-44">[44]</a></sup> In 1534, French explorer Jacques Cartier explored the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Saint_Lawrence" title="Gulf of Saint Lawrence">Gulf of Saint Lawrence</a> where, on July 24, he planted a 10-metre (33 ft) cross bearing the words "Long Live the King of France" and took possession of the territory New France in the name of <a href="/wiki/Francis_I_of_France" title="Francis I of France">King Francis I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> The early 16th century saw European mariners with navigational techniques pioneered by the <a href="/wiki/Basques" title="Basques">Basque</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_discoveries" title="Portuguese discoveries">Portuguese</a> establish seasonal whaling and fishing outposts along the Atlantic coast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kerr1987n_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kerr1987n-46">[46]</a></sup> In general, early settlements during the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a> appear to have been <a href="/wiki/Population_of_Canada#Ephemeral_European_settlements" title="Population of Canada">short-lived</a> due to a combination of the harsh climate, problems with navigating trade routes and competing outputs in Scandinavia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wynn2007_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wynn2007-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1583, Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a>, by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_prerogative" title="Royal prerogative">royal prerogative</a> of Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_I" title="Elizabeth I">Elizabeth I</a>, founded <a href="/wiki/St._John%27s,_Newfoundland_and_Labrador" title="St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador">St. John's, Newfoundland</a>, as the first North American <a href="/wiki/English_overseas_possessions" title="English overseas possessions">English seasonal camp</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> In 1600, the French established their first seasonal trading post at <a href="/wiki/Tadoussac" title="Tadoussac">Tadoussac</a> along the Saint Lawrence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CordellLightfoot2008_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-CordellLightfoot2008-43">[43]</a></sup> French explorer <a href="/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain" title="Samuel de Champlain">Samuel de Champlain</a> arrived in 1603 and established the first permanent year-round European settlements at <a href="/wiki/Port_Royal,_Annapolis_County,_Nova_Scotia" title="Port Royal, Annapolis County, Nova Scotia">Port Royal</a> (in 1605) and Quebec City (in 1608).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> Among the <a href="/wiki/French_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="French colonization of the Americas">colonists</a> of New France, <i><a href="/wiki/French_Canadians" title="French Canadians">Canadiens</a></i> extensively settled the Saint Lawrence River valley and <a href="/wiki/Acadians" title="Acadians">Acadians</a> settled the present-day <a href="/wiki/The_Maritimes" title="The Maritimes">Maritimes</a>, while fur traders and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_the_Age_of_Discovery" title="Catholic Church and the Age of Discovery">Catholic missionaries</a> explored the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Bay" title="Hudson Bay">Hudson Bay</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mississippi_watershed" title="Mississippi watershed">Mississippi watershed</a> to <a href="/wiki/Louisiana_(New_France)" title="Louisiana (New France)">Louisiana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Beaver_Wars" title="Beaver Wars">Beaver Wars</a> broke out in the mid-17th century over control of the North American fur trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>The English established additional settlements in <a href="/wiki/Newfoundland_(island)" title="Newfoundland (island)">Newfoundland</a> in 1610 along with settlements in the <a href="/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies" title="Thirteen Colonies">Thirteen Colonies</a> to the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hornsby_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-hornsby-54">[54]</a></sup> A series of <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_Wars" title="French and Indian Wars">four wars</a> erupted in colonial North America between 1689 and 1763; the later wars of the period constituted the North American theatre of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Mainland <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> came under British rule with the 1713 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Utrecht" title="Treaty of Utrecht">Treaty of Utrecht</a>, and Canada and most of New France came under British rule in 1763 after the Seven Years' War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="British_North_America">British North America</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_West_005.jpg"><img alt="Painting of General Wolfe dying in front of the British flag while attended by officers and native allies" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Benjamin_West_005.jpg/220px-Benjamin_West_005.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Benjamin_West_005.jpg/330px-Benjamin_West_005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Benjamin_West_005.jpg/440px-Benjamin_West_005.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Benjamin_West_005.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Benjamin_West" title="Benjamin West">Benjamin West</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Death_of_General_Wolfe" title="The Death of General Wolfe">The Death of General Wolfe</a></i> (1771) dramatizes <a href="/wiki/James_Wolfe" title="James Wolfe">James Wolfe</a>'s death during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Plains_of_Abraham" title="Battle of the Plains of Abraham">Battle of the Plains of Abraham</a> at <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City" title="Quebec City">Quebec</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Proclamation_of_1763" title="Royal Proclamation of 1763">Royal Proclamation of 1763</a> established First Nation treaty rights, created the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Quebec_(1763%E2%80%931791)" title="Province of Quebec (1763–1791)">Province of Quebec</a> out of New France, and annexed <a href="/wiki/Cape_Breton_Island" title="Cape Breton Island">Cape Breton Island</a> to Nova Scotia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-buckner_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-19">[19]</a></sup> St. John's Island (now <a href="/wiki/Prince_Edward_Island" title="Prince Edward Island">Prince Edward Island</a>) became a separate colony in 1769.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> To avert conflict in Quebec, the British Parliament passed the <a href="/wiki/Quebec_Act" title="Quebec Act">Quebec Act</a> 1774, expanding Quebec's territory to the Great Lakes and <a href="/wiki/Ohio_River" title="Ohio River">Ohio Valley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hopkins1898_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hopkins1898-58">[58]</a></sup> More importantly, the <i>Quebec Act</i> afforded Quebec special autonomy and rights of self-administration at a time when the Thirteen Colonies were increasingly agitating against British rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> It re-established the French language, Catholic faith, and <a href="/wiki/Law_of_France" title="Law of France">French civil law</a> there, staving off the growth of an independence movement in contrast to the Thirteen Colonies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StuartSavage2011_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-StuartSavage2011-60">[60]</a></sup> The Proclamation and the Quebec Act in turn angered many residents of the Thirteen Colonies, further fuelling anti-British sentiment in the years prior to the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-buckner_19-2"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the successful American War of Independence, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1783)" title="Treaty of Paris (1783)">1783 Treaty of Paris</a> recognized the independence of the newly formed <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> and set the terms of peace, ceding <a href="/wiki/British_North_America" title="British North America">British North American</a> territories south of the Great Lakes and east of the Mississippi River to the new country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> The American war of independence also caused a large out-migration of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Loyalists" title="Loyalists">Loyalists</a>, the settlers who had fought against American independence. Many moved to Canada, particularly Atlantic Canada, where their arrival changed the demographic distribution of the existing territories. <a href="/wiki/New_Brunswick" title="New Brunswick">New Brunswick</a> was in turn split from Nova Scotia as part of a reorganization of Loyalist settlements in the Maritimes, which led to the incorporation of <a href="/wiki/Saint_John,_New_Brunswick" title="Saint John, New Brunswick">Saint John, New Brunswick</a>, as Canada's first city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newman2016_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-Newman2016-62">[62]</a></sup> To accommodate the influx of English-speaking Loyalists in Central Canada, the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Act_1791" title="Constitutional Act 1791"><i>Constitutional Act</i> of 1791</a> divided the province of Canada into French-speaking Lower Canada (later <a href="/wiki/Quebec" title="Quebec">Quebec</a>) and English-speaking Upper Canada (later <a href="/wiki/Ontario#Canada_West" title="Ontario">Ontario</a>), granting each its own elected legislative assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons,_1813.jpg"><img alt="Painting of Laura Secord warning British commander James FitzGibbon of an impending American attack at Beaver Dams" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="472" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg/220px-Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg/330px-Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg/440px-Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons%2C_1813.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Laura_Secord_warns_Fitzgibbons,_1813.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">War of 1812</a> heroine <a href="/wiki/Laura_Secord" title="Laura Secord">Laura Secord</a> warning British commander <a href="/wiki/James_FitzGibbon" title="James FitzGibbon">James FitzGibbon</a> of an <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Beaver_Dams" title="Battle of Beaver Dams">impending American attack at Beaver Dams</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Canadas were the main front in the <a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">War of 1812</a> between the United States and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom</a>. Peace came in 1815; no boundaries were changed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarrisonFriesen2010_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-HarrisonFriesen2010-64">[64]</a></sup> Immigration resumed at a higher level, with over 960,000 arrivals from Britain between 1815 and 1850.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> New arrivals included refugees escaping the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Irish_Famine" title="Great Irish Famine">Great Irish Famine</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Gaelic</a>-speaking Scots displaced by the <a href="/wiki/Highland_Clearances" title="Highland Clearances">Highland Clearances</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Infectious diseases killed between 25 and 33 percent of Europeans who immigrated to Canada before 1891.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dying_28-2"><a href="#cite_note-dying-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>The desire for <a href="/wiki/Responsible_government" title="Responsible government">responsible government</a> resulted in the abortive <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rebellions_of_1837" title="Rebellions of 1837">Rebellions of 1837</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Read1985_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Read1985-67">[67]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Durham_Report" title="Durham Report">Durham Report</a> subsequently recommended responsible government and the assimilation of French Canadians into English culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-buckner_19-3"><a href="#cite_note-buckner-19">[19]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Union_1840" title="Act of Union 1840">Act of Union 1840</a> merged the Canadas into a united Province of Canada and responsible government was established for all provinces of British North America east of Lake Superior by 1855.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> The signing of the <a href="/wiki/Oregon_Treaty" title="Oregon Treaty">Oregon Treaty</a> by Britain and the United States in 1846 ended the <a href="/wiki/Oregon_boundary_dispute" title="Oregon boundary dispute">Oregon boundary dispute</a>, extending the border westward along the <a href="/wiki/49th_parallel_north" title="49th parallel north">49th parallel</a>. This paved the way for British colonies on <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_Vancouver_Island" title="Colony of Vancouver Island">Vancouver Island (1849)</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_British_Columbia_(1858%E2%80%931866)" title="Colony of British Columbia (1858–1866)">British Columbia (1858)</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> The Anglo-Russian <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Saint_Petersburg_(1825)" title="Treaty of Saint Petersburg (1825)">Treaty of Saint Petersburg (1825)</a> established the border along the Pacific coast, but, even after the US <a href="/wiki/Alaska_Purchase" title="Alaska Purchase">Alaska Purchase</a> of 1867, disputes continued about the exact demarcation of the Alaska–Yukon and Alaska–BC border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Confederation_and_expansion">Confederation and expansion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif"><img alt="Refer to caption" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="864" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif/260px-Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif/390px-Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif/520px-Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Canada_provinces_evolution_2.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Animated map showing <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_Canada" title="Territorial evolution of Canada">the growth and change of Canada's provinces and territories</a> since Confederation in 1867</div></div></div>
<p>Following several constitutional conferences, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1867" title="Constitution Act, 1867">British North America Act 1867</a> officially proclaimed Canadian Confederation on July 1, 1867, initially with four provinces: <a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">Ontario</a>, Quebec, Nova Scotia, and New Brunswick.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bothwell_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-bothwell-72">[72]</a></sup> Canada assumed control of <a href="/wiki/Rupert%27s_Land" title="Rupert's Land">Rupert's Land</a> and the <a href="/wiki/North-Western_Territory" title="North-Western Territory">North-Western Territory</a> to form the <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Territories" title="Northwest Territories">Northwest Territories</a>, where the Métis' grievances ignited the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Rebellion" title="Red River Rebellion">Red River Rebellion</a> and the creation of the province of <a href="/wiki/Manitoba" title="Manitoba">Manitoba</a> in July 1870.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> British Columbia and Vancouver Island (which <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_British_Columbia_(1866%E2%80%931871)" title="Colony of British Columbia (1866–1871)">had been united</a> in 1866) joined the confederation in 1871 on the promise of a transcontinental railway extending to Victoria in the province within 10 years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> while Prince Edward Island joined in 1873.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-canatlas_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-canatlas-75">[75]</a></sup> In 1898, during the <a href="/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush" title="Klondike Gold Rush">Klondike Gold Rush</a> in the Northwest Territories, Parliament created the Yukon Territory. <a href="/wiki/Alberta" title="Alberta">Alberta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saskatchewan" title="Saskatchewan">Saskatchewan</a> became provinces in 1905.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-canatlas_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-canatlas-75">[75]</a></sup> Between 1871 and 1896, almost one quarter of the Canadian population emigrated south to the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mdmols_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-mdmols-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>To open <a href="/wiki/Western_Canada" title="Western Canada">the West</a> and encourage European immigration, Parliament approved sponsoring the construction of three transcontinental railways (including the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Pacific_Railway" title="Canadian Pacific Railway">Canadian Pacific Railway</a>), opening the prairies to settlement with the <i><a href="/wiki/Dominion_Lands_Act" title="Dominion Lands Act">Dominion Lands Act</a></i>, and establishing the <a href="/wiki/North-West_Mounted_Police" title="North-West Mounted Police">North-West Mounted Police</a> to assert its authority over this territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> This <a href="/wiki/Post-Confederation_Canada_(1867%E2%80%931914)#Expansion" title="Post-Confederation Canada (1867–1914)">period of westward expansion</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Policy" title="National Policy">nation building</a> resulted in the displacement of many <a href="/wiki/Plains_Indians" title="Plains Indians">Indigenous peoples of the Canadian Prairies</a> to "<a href="/wiki/Indian_reserve" title="Indian reserve">Indian reserves</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hele2013_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hele2013-79">[79]</a></sup> clearing the way for ethnic European <a href="/wiki/Block_settlement" title="Block settlement">block settlements</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> This caused the collapse of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_bison_conservation_in_Canada#Plains_bison" title="History of bison conservation in Canada">Plains Bison in western Canada</a> and the introduction of European <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Canada" title="Agriculture in Canada">cattle farms and wheat fields</a> dominating the land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArmitagePlummer2010_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-ArmitagePlummer2010-81">[81]</a></sup> The Indigenous peoples saw widespread famine and disease due to the loss of the bison and their traditional hunting lands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daschuk2013_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Daschuk2013-82">[82]</a></sup> The federal government did provide emergency relief, on condition of the Indigenous peoples moving to the reserves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hall2015_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hall2015-83">[83]</a></sup> During this time, Canada introduced the <i><a href="/wiki/Indian_Act" title="Indian Act">Indian Act</a></i> extending its control over the First Nations to education, government and legal rights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JacksonJackson2020_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-JacksonJackson2020-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_20th_century">Early 20th century</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:279px;max-width:279px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader"><span style="font-size:85%;">1918 <a href="/wiki/Canada_Savings_Bond" title="Canada Savings Bond">Canadian War bond posters</a> depicting three French women pulling a plow that had been constructed for horses.</span></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:137px;max-width:137px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:198px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3806" data-file-width="2601" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg/135px-Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg/203px-Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg/270px-Canada_WWI_l%27Emprunt_de_la_Victoire2.jpg 2x" width="135"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">French version of the poster roughly translates as "They serve France–Everyone can serve; Buy Victory Bonds".</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:138px;max-width:138px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:198px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3805" data-file-width="2601" decoding="async" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg/136px-Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg/204px-Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg/272px-Canada_WWI_Victory_Bonds2.jpg 2x" width="136"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The same poster in English, with subtle differences in text. "They serve France—How can I serve Canada? Buy Victory Bonds".</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Because Britain still maintained control of Canada's foreign affairs under the British North America Act, 1867, its declaration of war in 1914 automatically brought <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Canada_during_World_War_I" title="Military history of Canada during World War I">Canada into World War I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> Volunteers sent to the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western Front</a> later became part of the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Corps" title="Canadian Corps">Canadian Corps</a>, which played a substantial role in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vimy_Ridge" title="Battle of Vimy Ridge">Battle of Vimy Ridge</a> and other major engagements of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> Out of approximately 625,000 Canadians who served in World War I, some 60,000 were killed and another 172,000 were wounded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1917" title="Conscription Crisis of 1917">Conscription Crisis of 1917</a> erupted when the <a href="/wiki/Unionist_Party_(Canada)" title="Unionist Party (Canada)">Unionist</a> Cabinet's proposal to augment the military's dwindling number of active members with <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> was met with vehement objections from French-speaking Quebecers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McGonigal1962_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-McGonigal1962-88">[88]</a></sup> The <i>Military Service Act</i> brought in compulsory military service, though it, coupled with disputes over French language schools outside Quebec, deeply alienated Francophone Canadians and temporarily split the Liberal Party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McGonigal1962_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-McGonigal1962-88">[88]</a></sup> In 1919, Canada joined the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> independently of Britain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> and the Statute of Westminster, 1931 affirmed Canada's independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morton2002_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-Morton2002-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression_in_Canada" title="Great Depression in Canada">Great Depression in Canada</a> during the early 1930s saw an economic downturn, leading to hardship across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> In response to the downturn, the <a href="/wiki/Co-operative_Commonwealth_Federation" title="Co-operative Commonwealth Federation">Co-operative Commonwealth Federation</a> (CCF) in Saskatchewan introduced many elements of a <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a> (as pioneered by <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Douglas" title="Tommy Douglas">Tommy Douglas</a>) in the 1940s and 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> On the advice of Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/William_Lyon_Mackenzie_King" title="William Lyon Mackenzie King">William Lyon Mackenzie King</a>, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war_by_Canada#Nazi_Germany" title="Declaration of war by Canada">war with Germany was declared</a> effective September 10, 1939, by King <a href="/wiki/George_VI" title="George VI">George VI</a>, seven days after the United Kingdom. The delay underscored Canada's independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-2"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first Canadian Army units arrived in Britain in December 1939. In all, over a million Canadians served in the armed forces during World War II and approximately 42,000 were killed and another 55,000 were wounded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Canadian troops played important roles in many key battles of the war, including the failed 1942 <a href="/wiki/Dieppe_Raid" title="Dieppe Raid">Dieppe Raid</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Italy" title="Allied invasion of Italy">Allied invasion of Italy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Normandy_landings" title="Normandy landings">Normandy landings</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Overlord" title="Operation Overlord">Battle of Normandy</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Scheldt" title="Battle of the Scheldt">Battle of the Scheldt</a> in 1944.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-3"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> Canada provided asylum for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dutch_monarchy" title="Dutch monarchy">Dutch monarchy</a> while that country was <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Niederlande" title="Reichskommissariat Niederlande">occupied</a> and is credited by the Netherlands for major contributions to <a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day_(Netherlands)" title="Liberation Day (Netherlands)">its liberation</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-netherlands_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-netherlands-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Canadian economy boomed during the war as its industries manufactured military <a href="/wiki/Materiel" title="Materiel">materiel</a> for Canada, Britain, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">China</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-4"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> Despite another <a href="/wiki/Conscription_Crisis_of_1944" title="Conscription Crisis of 1944">Conscription Crisis</a> in Quebec in 1944, Canada finished the war with a large army and strong economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_era">Contemporary era</span></h3>
<p>The financial crisis of the Great Depression had led the <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Newfoundland" title="Dominion of Newfoundland">Dominion of Newfoundland</a> to relinquish responsible government in 1934 and become a <a href="/wiki/Crown_colony" title="Crown colony">Crown colony</a> ruled by a British governor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buckner20082ed_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-Buckner20082ed-95">[95]</a></sup> After two <a href="/wiki/1948_Newfoundland_referendums" title="1948 Newfoundland referendums">referendums</a>, Newfoundlanders voted to join Canada in 1949 as a province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada's post-war economic growth, combined with the policies of successive Liberal governments, led to the emergence of a new <a href="/wiki/Canadian_identity" title="Canadian identity">Canadian identity</a>, marked by the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Canada" title="Flag of Canada">Maple Leaf Flag</a> in 1965,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> the implementation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Official_bilingualism" title="Official bilingualism">official bilingualism</a> (English and French) in 1969,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> and the institution of <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism#Canada" title="Multiculturalism">official multiculturalism</a> in 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">Socially democratic</a> programs were also instituted, such as <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(Canada)" title="Medicare (Canada)">Medicare</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Canada_Pension_Plan" title="Canada Pension Plan">Canada Pension Plan</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Student_financial_aid_(Canada)" title="Student financial aid (Canada)">Canada Student Loans</a>, though provincial governments, particularly Quebec and Alberta, opposed many of these as incursions into their jurisdictions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg"><img alt="refer to caption" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="309" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="201" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg/260px-Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg/390px-Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Canadiancharterofrightsandfreedoms.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A copy of the <i><a href="/wiki/Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>Finally, another series of constitutional conferences resulted in the UK's <a href="/wiki/Canada_Act_1982" title="Canada Act 1982">Canada Act 1982</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Patriation" title="Patriation">patriation</a> of Canada's constitution from the United Kingdom, concurrent with the creation of the <i><a href="/wiki/Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Canada had established complete sovereignty as an independent country, although the monarch is retained as <a href="/wiki/Sovereign" title="Sovereign">sovereign</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bickerton_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-bickerton-105">[105]</a></sup> In 1999, <a href="/wiki/Nunavut" title="Nunavut">Nunavut</a> became Canada's third territory after a series of negotiations with the federal government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the same time, Quebec underwent profound social and economic changes through the <a href="/wiki/Quiet_Revolution" title="Quiet Revolution">Quiet Revolution</a> of the 1960s, giving birth to a secular <a href="/wiki/Quebec_nationalism" title="Quebec nationalism">nationalist</a> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RobertsClifton2005_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-RobertsClifton2005-107">[107]</a></sup> The radical <a href="/wiki/Front_de_lib%C3%A9ration_du_Qu%C3%A9bec" title="Front de libération du Québec">Front de libération du Québec</a> (FLQ) ignited the <a href="/wiki/October_Crisis" title="October Crisis">October Crisis</a> with a series of bombings and kidnappings in 1970<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Quebec_sovereignty_movement" title="Quebec sovereignty movement">sovereignist</a> <a href="/wiki/Parti_Qu%C3%A9b%C3%A9cois" title="Parti Québécois">Parti Québécois</a> was elected in 1976, organizing an <a href="/wiki/1980_Quebec_referendum" title="1980 Quebec referendum">unsuccessful referendum</a> on sovereignty-association in 1980. Attempts to accommodate Quebec nationalism constitutionally through the <a href="/wiki/Meech_Lake_Accord" title="Meech Lake Accord">Meech Lake Accord</a> failed in 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sorens_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-sorens-109">[109]</a></sup> This led to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Bloc_Qu%C3%A9b%C3%A9cois" title="Bloc Québécois">Bloc Québécois</a> in Quebec and the invigoration of the <a href="/wiki/Reform_Party_of_Canada" title="Reform Party of Canada">Reform Party of Canada</a> in the West.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/1995_Quebec_referendum" title="1995 Quebec referendum">second referendum</a> followed in 1995, in which sovereignty was rejected by a slimmer margin of 50.6 to 49.4 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> In 1997, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Canada" title="Supreme Court of Canada">Supreme Court</a> ruled <a href="/wiki/Reference_Re_Secession_of_Quebec" title="Reference Re Secession of Quebec">unilateral secession</a> by a province would be unconstitutional and the <i><a href="/wiki/Clarity_Act" title="Clarity Act">Clarity Act</a></i> was passed by parliament, outlining the terms of a negotiated departure from Confederation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sorens_109-1"><a href="#cite_note-sorens-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to the issues of Quebec sovereignty, a number of crises shook Canadian society in the late 1980s and early 1990s. These included the explosion of <a href="/wiki/Air_India_Flight_182" title="Air India Flight 182">Air India Flight 182</a> in 1985, the largest mass murder in Canadian history;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/%C3%89cole_Polytechnique_massacre" title="École Polytechnique massacre">École Polytechnique massacre</a> in 1989, a <a href="/wiki/School_shooting" title="School shooting">university shooting</a> targeting female students;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Oka_Crisis" title="Oka Crisis">Oka Crisis</a> of 1990,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> the first of a number of violent confrontations between the government and Indigenous groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Canada also joined the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> in 1990 as part of a United States–led coalition force and was active in several peacekeeping missions in the 1990s, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNPROFOR" title="UNPROFOR">UNPROFOR</a> mission in the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars" title="Yugoslav Wars">former Yugoslavia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Canada sent <a href="/wiki/Canada_in_the_War_in_Afghanistan" title="Canada in the War in Afghanistan">troops to Afghanistan in 2001</a> but declined to join the United States–led <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">invasion of Iraq in 2003</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, Canadian forces participated in the NATO-led intervention into the <a href="/wiki/First_Libyan_Civil_War" title="First Libyan Civil War">Libyan Civil War</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HehirMurray2013_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-HehirMurray2013-119">[119]</a></sup> and also became involved in battling the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State" title="Islamic State">Islamic State</a> insurgency in Iraq in the mid-2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Canada" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Canada">COVID-19 pandemic in Canada</a> began on January 27, 2020, with wide social and economic disruption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> In 2021, the remains of <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Indian_residential_school_gravesites" title="Canadian Indian residential school gravesites">hundreds of Indigenous people were discovered</a> near the former sites of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadian_Indian_residential_school" title="Canadian Indian residential school">Canadian Indian residential schools</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> Administered by the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Canada" title="Catholic Church in Canada">Canadian Catholic Church</a> and funded by the Canadian government from 1828 to 1997, these <a href="/wiki/Boarding_school" title="Boarding school">boarding schools</a> attempted to assimilate Indigenous children into <a href="/wiki/European_Canadians#Culture" title="European Canadians">Euro-Canadian culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canada2016_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-Canada2016-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Canada" title="Geography of Canada">Geography of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canada_topo.jpg"><img alt="refer to caption" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1211" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Canada_topo.jpg/260px-Canada_topo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Canada_topo.jpg/390px-Canada_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Canada_topo.jpg/520px-Canada_topo.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Canada_topo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A topographic map of Canada, in polar projection (for 90° W), showing elevations shaded from green to brown (higher)</div></div></div>
<p>By total area (including its waters), Canada is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">second-largest country</a> in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BresciaSuper2009_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-BresciaSuper2009-124">[124]</a></sup> By land area alone, Canada <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">ranks fourth</a>, due to having the world's largest area of <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_Canada" title="List of lakes of Canada">fresh water lakes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Battram2010da_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-Battram2010da-125">[125]</a></sup> Stretching from the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> in the east, along the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Ocean" title="Arctic Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a> to the north, and to the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> in the west, the country encompasses 9,984,670 km<sup>2</sup> (3,855,100 sq mi) of territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McColl2005_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-McColl2005-126">[126]</a></sup> Canada also has vast maritime terrain, with the world's longest coastline of 243,042 kilometres (151,019 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> In addition to sharing the <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Canada–United States border">world's largest land border with the United States</a>—spanning 8,891 km (5,525 mi)—Canada shares a land border with <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> (and hence the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Denmark" title="Kingdom of Denmark">Kingdom of Denmark</a>) to the northeast on <a href="/wiki/Hans_Island" title="Hans Island">Hans Island</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime boundary</a> with <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Overseas_collectivity" title="Overseas collectivity">overseas collectivity</a> of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Pierre_and_Miquelon" title="Saint Pierre and Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a> to the southeast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gallay2015_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gallay2015-130">[130]</a></sup> Canada is also home to the world's northernmost settlement, <a href="/wiki/CFS_Alert" title="CFS Alert">Canadian Forces Station Alert</a>, on the northern tip of <a href="/wiki/Ellesmere_Island" title="Ellesmere Island">Ellesmere Island</a>—latitude 82.5°N—which lies 817 kilometres (508 mi) from the North Pole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada can be divided into seven physiographic regions: the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Shield" title="Canadian Shield">Canadian Shield</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interior_plains" title="Interior plains">interior plains</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Lakes-St._Lawrence_Lowlands" title="Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Lowlands">Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Lowlands</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachian region</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Cordillera_(Canada)" title="Pacific Cordillera (Canada)">Western Cordillera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Bay_Lowlands" title="Hudson Bay Lowlands">Hudson Bay Lowlands</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Archipelago" title="Arctic Archipelago">Arctic Archipelago</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlas_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atlas-132">[132]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">Boreal forests</a> prevail throughout the country, ice is prominent in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Canada" title="Northern Canada">northern Arctic regions</a> and through the <a href="/wiki/Rocky_Mountains" title="Rocky Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a>, and the relatively flat <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Prairies" title="Canadian Prairies">Canadian Prairies</a> in the southwest facilitate productive agriculture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McColl2005_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-McColl2005-126">[126]</a></sup> The Great Lakes feed the <a href="/wiki/St._Lawrence_River" title="St. Lawrence River">St. Lawrence River</a> (in the southeast) where the lowlands host much of Canada's economic output.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McColl2005_126-2"><a href="#cite_note-McColl2005-126">[126]</a></sup> Canada has over 2,000,000 lakes—563 of which are larger than 100 km<sup>2</sup> (39 sq mi)—containing much of the world's <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> There are also fresh-water glaciers in the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Rockies" title="Canadian Rockies">Canadian Rockies</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Coast_Mountains" title="Coast Mountains">Coast Mountains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Cordillera" title="Arctic Cordillera">Arctic Cordillera</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sandford2012_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sandford2012-135">[135]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Canada" title="Geology of Canada">Canada is geologically active</a>, having <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Canada" title="List of earthquakes in Canada">many earthquakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volcanism_of_Canada" title="Volcanism of Canada">potentially active volcanoes</a>, notably <a href="/wiki/Mount_Meager_massif" title="Mount Meager massif">Mount Meager massif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Garibaldi" title="Mount Garibaldi">Mount Garibaldi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Cayley" title="Mount Cayley">Mount Cayley</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Mount_Edziza_volcanic_complex" title="Mount Edziza volcanic complex">Mount Edziza volcanic complex</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Temperature_in_Canada" title="Temperature in Canada">Temperature in Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1278" data-file-width="1170" decoding="async" height="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/260px-Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/390px-Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/520px-Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Canada_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Köppen climate classification types of Canada</div></div></div>
<p>Average winter and summer high <a href="/wiki/Temperature_in_Canada" title="Temperature in Canada">temperatures across Canada</a> vary from region to region. Winters can be harsh in many parts of the country, particularly in the interior and Prairie provinces, which experience a <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a>, where daily average temperatures are near −15 <a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">°C</a> (5 <a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">°F</a>), but can drop below −40 °C (−40 °F) with severe <a href="/wiki/Wind_chill" title="Wind chill">wind chills</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> In non-coastal regions, snow can cover the ground for almost six months of the year, while in parts of the north snow can persist year-round. Coastal British Columbia has a temperate climate, with a mild and rainy winter. On the east and west coasts, average high temperatures are generally in the low 20s °C (70s °F), while between the coasts, the average summer high temperature ranges from 25 to 30 °C (77 to 86 °F), with temperatures in some interior locations occasionally exceeding 40 °C (104 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ccnRegina_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-ccnRegina-138">[138]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of <a href="/wiki/Northern_Canada" title="Northern Canada">Northern Canada</a> is covered by ice and <a href="/wiki/Permafrost" title="Permafrost">permafrost</a>.
