The future of the permafrost is uncertain because the Arctic has been warming at three times the global average as a result of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Canada" title="Climate change in Canada">climate change in Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Canada's annual average temperature over land has warmed by 1.7 °C (3.1 °F), with changes ranging from 1.1 to 2.3 °C (2.0 to 4.1 °F) in various regions, since 1948.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ClimateReport_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-ClimateReport-140">[140]</a></sup> The rate of warming has been higher across the North and in the Prairies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ClimateReport_140-1"><a href="#cite_note-ClimateReport-140">[140]</a></sup> In the southern regions of Canada, <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_Canada" title="Air pollution in Canada">air pollution from both Canada</a> and the United States—caused by metal smelting, burning coal to power utilities, and vehicle emissions—has resulted in <a href="/wiki/Acid_rain" title="Acid rain">acid rain</a>, which has severely impacted waterways, forest growth and agricultural productivity in Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boyd2011_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boyd2011-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Canada" title="Wildlife of Canada">Wildlife of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada,_2017.gif"><img alt="Map showing Canada divided into different ecozones" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="606" data-file-width="710" decoding="async" height="222" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif/260px-Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif/390px-Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif/520px-Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada%2C_2017.gif 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Terrestrial_ecozones_and_ecoprovinces_of_Canada,_2017.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ecozones_of_Canada" title="Ecozones of Canada">Terrestrial ecozones and ecoprovinces of Canada</a>. Ecozones are identified with a unique colour. Ecoprovinces are subdivisions of ecozones and are identified with a unique numeric code</div></div></div>
<p>Canada is divided into <a href="/wiki/Ecozones_of_Canada" title="Ecozones of Canada">fifteen terrestrial and five marine ecozones</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-intro_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-intro-142">[142]</a></sup> These ecozones encompass over 80,000 classified species of <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Canada" title="Wildlife of Canada">Canadian wildlife</a>, with an equal number yet to be formally recognized or discovered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Species_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-Species-143">[143]</a></sup> Although Canada has a low percentage of <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">endemic species compared to other countries</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> due to human activities, <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Canada#Invasive_species" title="Wildlife of Canada">invasive species</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Canada" title="Environmental issues in Canada">environmental issues in the country</a>, there are currently more than <a href="/wiki/List_of_Wildlife_Species_at_Risk_(Canada)" title="List of Wildlife Species at Risk (Canada)">800 species at risk of being lost</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-COSEWIC_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-COSEWIC-145">[145]</a></sup> About 65 percent of Canada’s resident species are considered "Secure".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-146">[146]</a></sup> Over half of Canada's landscape is intact and relatively free of human development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Boreal_forest_of_Canada" title="Boreal forest of Canada">boreal forest of Canada</a> is considered to be the largest <a href="/wiki/Intact_forest_landscape" title="Intact forest landscape">intact forest</a> on Earth, with approximately 3,000,000 km<sup>2</sup> (1,200,000 sq mi) undisturbed by roads, cities or industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RavenBerg2012_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-RavenBerg2012-148">[148]</a></sup> Since the end of the last <a href="/wiki/Glacial_period" title="Glacial period">glacial period</a>, Canada has consisted of <a href="/wiki/Forests_of_Canada#Regions" title="Forests of Canada">eight distinct forest regions</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> with 42 percent of its land area covered by forests (approximately 8 percent of the world's forested land).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LuckertHaley2011_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-LuckertHaley2011-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p><p>Approximately 12.1 percent of the nation's landmass and freshwater are <a href="/wiki/National_Wildlife_Area" title="National Wildlife Area">conservation areas</a>, including 11.4 percent designated as <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Canada" title="Protected areas of Canada">protected areas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conserved_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-conserved-151">[151]</a></sup> Approximately 13.8 percent of its territorial waters are conserved, including 8.9 percent designated as protected areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conserved_151-1"><a href="#cite_note-conserved-151">[151]</a></sup> Canada's first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Parks_of_Canada" title="National Parks of Canada">National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banff_National_Park" title="Banff National Park">Banff National Park</a> established in 1885, spans 6,641 square kilometres (2,564 sq mi)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> of mountainous terrain, with many <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">glaciers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ice_field" title="Ice field">ice fields</a>, dense <a href="/wiki/Conifer" title="Conifer">coniferous</a> forest, and alpine landscapes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Price2013_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Price2013-153">[153]</a></sup> Canada's oldest provincial park, <a href="/wiki/Algonquin_Provincial_Park" title="Algonquin Provincial Park">Algonquin Provincial Park</a>, established in 1893, covers an area of 7,653.45 square kilometres (2,955.01 sq mi). It is dominated by <a href="/wiki/Old-growth_forest" title="Old-growth forest">old-growth forest</a> with over 2,400 lakes and 1,200 kilometres of streams and rivers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lake_Superior_National_Marine_Conservation_Area" title="Lake Superior National Marine Conservation Area">Lake Superior National Marine Conservation Area</a> is the world's largest freshwater protected area, spanning roughly 10,000 square kilometres (3,900 sq mi) of lakebed, its overlaying freshwater, and associated shoreline on 60 square kilometres (23 sq mi) of islands and mainland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> Canada's largest national wildlife region is the <a href="/wiki/Scott_Islands_Marine_National_Wildlife_Area" title="Scott Islands Marine National Wildlife Area">Scott Islands Marine National Wildlife Area</a>, which spans 11,570.65 square kilometres (4,467.45 sq mi)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> and protects critical breeding and nesting habitat for over 40 percent of British Columbia's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seabirds" title="Seabirds">seabirds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> Canada's 18 <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_Reserves_of_Canada" title="Biosphere Reserves of Canada">UNESCO Biosphere Reserves</a> cover a total area of 235,000 square kilometres (91,000 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Canada" title="Politics of Canada">Politics of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parliamenthill.jpg"><img alt="A building with a central clock tower rising from a block" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3220" data-file-width="4260" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parliamenthill.jpg/220px-Parliamenthill.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parliamenthill.jpg/330px-Parliamenthill.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parliamenthill.jpg/440px-Parliamenthill.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parliamenthill.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Parliament_Hill" title="Parliament Hill">Parliament Hill</a>, home of the federal government in Canada's capital city, <a href="/wiki/Ottawa" title="Ottawa">Ottawa</a></div></div></div>
<p>Canada is described as a "<a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">full democracy</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> with a tradition of <a href="/wiki/Liberalism" title="Liberalism">liberalism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WesthuesWharf2014_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-WesthuesWharf2014-160">[160]</a></sup> and an <a href="/wiki/Egalitarianism" title="Egalitarianism">egalitarian</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BickertonGagnon2009_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-BickertonGagnon2009-161">[161]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Political_moderate" title="Political moderate">moderate</a> political ideology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson2016_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson2016-162">[162]</a></sup> An emphasis on <a href="/wiki/Social_justice" title="Social justice">social justice</a> has been a distinguishing element of Canada's political culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McQuaig_2010_p._14_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-McQuaig_2010_p._14-163">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fierlbeck2006_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fierlbeck2006-164">[164]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peace,_order,_and_good_government" title="Peace, order, and good government">Peace, order, and good government</a>, alongside an <a href="/wiki/Implied_Bill_of_Rights" title="Implied Bill of Rights">Implied Bill of Rights</a>, are founding principles of the Canadian government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DixonScheurell2016_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-DixonScheurell2016-165">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boughey2017_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boughey2017-166">[166]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the federal level, Canada has been dominated by two relatively <a href="/wiki/Centrism" title="Centrism">centrist</a> parties practising "brokerage politics",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politics_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-politics-173">[a]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Centre-left_politics" title="Centre-left politics">centre-left</a> leaning <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Canada" title="Liberal Party of Canada">Liberal Party of Canada</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre-right" title="Centre-right">centre-right</a> leaning <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Canada" title="Conservative Party of Canada">Conservative Party of Canada</a> (or its <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Canada#Predecessors" title="Conservative Party of Canada">predecessors</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BaumerGold2015_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-BaumerGold2015-174">[173]</a></sup> The historically predominant Liberal Party position themselves at the centre of the Canadian political spectrum,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup> with the Conservative Party positioned on the right and the <a href="/wiki/New_Democratic_Party" title="New Democratic Party">New Democratic Party</a> occupying the <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_politics" title="Left-wing politics">left</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EvansGraaf2013_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-EvansGraaf2013-176">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnston2017_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-Johnston2017-177">[176]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Far-right" title="Far-right">Far-right</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Far-left" title="Far-left">far-left</a> politics have never been a prominent force in Canadian society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[178]</a></sup> Five parties had representatives elected to the Parliament in the <a href="/wiki/2021_Canadian_federal_election" title="2021 Canadian federal election">2021 election</a>—the Liberal Party, who currently form a minority government; the Conservative Party, who are the <a href="/wiki/Official_Opposition_(Canada)" title="Official Opposition (Canada)">Official Opposition</a>; the New Democratic Party; the <a href="/wiki/Bloc_Qu%C3%A9b%C3%A9cois" title="Bloc Québécois">Bloc Québécois</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Green_Party_of_Canada" title="Green Party of Canada">Green Party of Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada has a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> within the context of a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>—the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Canada" title="Monarchy of Canada">monarchy of Canada</a> being the foundation of the executive, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative" title="Legislative">legislative</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judicial" title="Judicial">judicial</a> branches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacLeod16_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-MacLeod16-183">[182]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Reign" title="Reign">reigning</a> monarch is King <span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Charles_III" title="Charles III">Charles III</a></span>, who is also monarch of <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">14 other Commonwealth countries</a> and each of Canada's 10 provinces. The person who is the Canadian monarch is the same as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_monarch" title="British monarch">British monarch</a>, although the two institutions are separate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson2018_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson2018-184">[183]</a></sup> The monarch appoints a representative, the <a href="/wiki/Governor_General_of_Canada" title="Governor General of Canada">governor general</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Advice_(constitutional_law)" title="Advice (constitutional law)">advice</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada" title="Prime Minister of Canada">prime minister</a>, to carry out most of their federal royal duties in Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>While the monarchy is the source of authority in Canada, in practice its position is mainly symbolic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacLeod16_183-1"><a href="#cite_note-MacLeod16-183">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forseyp1_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forseyp1-187">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Montpetit_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-Montpetit-188">[187]</a></sup> The use of the executive powers is directed by the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Canada" title="Cabinet of Canada">Cabinet</a>, a committee of <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_the_Crown" title="Minister of the Crown">ministers of the Crown</a> responsible to the elected <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_Canada" title="House of Commons of Canada">House of Commons</a> and chosen and headed by the prime minister (at present <a href="/wiki/Justin_Trudeau" title="Justin Trudeau">Justin Trudeau</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[188]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>. The governor general or monarch may, though, in certain crisis situations exercise their power without ministerial <a href="/wiki/Advice_(constitutional_law)" title="Advice (constitutional law)">advice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forseyp1_187-1"><a href="#cite_note-Forseyp1-187">[186]</a></sup> To ensure the stability of government, the governor general will usually appoint as prime minister the individual who is the current leader of the political party that can obtain the confidence of a <a href="/wiki/Plurality_(voting)" title="Plurality (voting)">plurality</a> in the House of Commons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_Prime_Minister_(Canada)" title="Office of the Prime Minister (Canada)">Prime Minister's Office</a> (PMO) is thus one of the most powerful institutions in government, initiating most legislation for parliamentary approval and selecting for appointment by the Crown, besides the aforementioned, the governor general, <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_(Canada)" title="Lieutenant Governor (Canada)">lieutenant governors</a>, senators, federal court judges, and heads of <a href="/wiki/Crown_corporations_of_Canada" title="Crown corporations of Canada">Crown corporations</a> and government agencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forseyp1_187-2"><a href="#cite_note-Forseyp1-187">[186]</a></sup> The leader of the party with the second-most seats usually becomes the <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Official_Opposition_(Canada)" title="Leader of the Official Opposition (Canada)">leader of the Official Opposition</a> and is part of an adversarial parliamentary system intended to keep the government in check.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[190]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cansenate.jpg"><img alt="Canadian Senate chamber long hall with two opposing banks of seats with historical paintings" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="854" data-file-width="1310" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cansenate.jpg/220px-Cansenate.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cansenate.jpg/330px-Cansenate.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Cansenate.jpg/440px-Cansenate.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cansenate.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Canada" title="Senate of Canada">Senate chamber</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Centre_Block" title="Centre Block">Centre Block</a> on <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Hill" title="Parliament Hill">Parliament Hill</a></div></div></div>
<p>Each of the 338 <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(Canada)" title="Member of Parliament (Canada)">members of Parliament</a> in the House of Commons is elected by simple plurality in an <a href="/wiki/Electoral_district_(Canada)" title="Electoral district (Canada)">electoral district</a> or riding. <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Canada" title="Elections in Canada">General elections in Canada</a> must be called by the governor general, either on the advice of the prime minister or if the government loses a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confidence_vote" title="Confidence vote">confidence vote</a> in the House.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[192]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1982" title="Constitution Act, 1982">Constitution Act, 1982</a></i> requires that no more than five years pass between elections, although the <i><a href="/wiki/Canada_Elections_Act" title="Canada Elections Act">Canada Elections Act</a></i> limits this to four years with a fixed election date in October. The 105 members of the Senate, whose seats are apportioned on a regional basis, serve until age 75.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Canadian_federalism" title="Canadian federalism">Canadian federalism</a> divides government responsibilities between the federal government and the ten provinces. <a href="/wiki/Legislative_assemblies_of_Canadian_provinces_and_territories" title="Legislative assemblies of Canadian provinces and territories">Provincial legislatures</a> are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> and operate in parliamentary fashion similar to the House of Commons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Montpetit_188-1"><a href="#cite_note-Montpetit-188">[187]</a></sup> Canada's three territories also have legislatures, but these are not sovereign and have fewer constitutional responsibilities than the provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[194]</a></sup> The territorial legislatures also differ structurally from their provincial counterparts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Canada" title="Bank of Canada">Bank of Canada</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> of the country. In addition, the <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Finance_(Canada)" title="Minister of Finance (Canada)">minister of finance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Innovation,_Science_and_Industry" title="Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry">minister of innovation, science and industry</a> utilize the <a href="/wiki/Statistics_Canada" title="Statistics Canada">Statistics Canada</a> agency for financial planning and economic policy development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup> The Bank of Canada is the sole authority authorized to issue currency in the form of <a href="/wiki/Banknotes_of_the_Canadian_dollar" title="Banknotes of the Canadian dollar">Canadian bank notes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GilbertHelleiner2003_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-GilbertHelleiner2003-198">[197]</a></sup> The bank does not issue <a href="/wiki/Coins_of_the_Canadian_dollar" title="Coins of the Canadian dollar">Canadian coins</a>; they are issued by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mint" title="Royal Canadian Mint">Royal Canadian Mint</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CuhajMichael2011_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-CuhajMichael2011-199">[198]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Canada" title="Law of Canada">Law of Canada</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Canada" title="Constitution of Canada">Constitution of Canada</a> is the supreme law of the country, and consists of written text and unwritten conventions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dodek2016_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dodek2016-200">[199]</a></sup> The <i>Constitution Act, 1867</i> (known as the <a href="/wiki/British_North_America_Acts" title="British North America Acts">British North America Act</a> prior to 1982), affirmed governance based on parliamentary precedent and divided powers between the federal and provincial governments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olive2015_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-Olive2015-201">[200]</a></sup> The Statute of Westminster, 1931 granted full autonomy, and the <i>Constitution Act, 1982</i> ended all legislative ties to Britain, as well as adding a constitutional amending formula and the <i>Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VishnooShirur1997_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-VishnooShirur1997-202">[201]</a></sup> The <i>Charter</i> guarantees basic rights and freedoms that usually cannot be over-ridden by any government—though a <a href="/wiki/Section_33_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Section 33 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">notwithstanding clause</a> allows Parliament and the provincial legislatures to override certain sections of the <i>Charter</i> for a period of five years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[202]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg"><img alt="Supreme Court of Canada building" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2360" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg/220px-Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg/330px-Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg/440px-Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Supreme_court_of_Canada_in_summer.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Canada" title="Supreme Court of Canada">Supreme Court of Canada</a> in Ottawa, west of Parliament Hill</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Court_system_of_Canada" title="Court system of Canada">Canada's judiciary</a> plays an important role in interpreting laws and has the power to strike down Acts of Parliament that violate the constitution. The Supreme Court of Canada is the highest court and final arbiter and has been led since December 18, 2017, by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Wagner_(judge)" title="Richard Wagner (judge)">Richard Wagner</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Canada" title="Chief Justice of Canada">chief justice of Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[203]</a></sup> The governor general appoints its nine members on the advice of the prime minister and <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Justice_and_Attorney_General_of_Canada" title="Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada">minister of justice</a>. All judges at the superior and appellate levels are appointed after consultation with non-governmental legal bodies. The federal Cabinet also appoints justices to superior courts in the provincial and territorial jurisdictions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">Common law</a> prevails everywhere except in Quebec, where <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> predominates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hermida2018b_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hermida2018b-206">[205]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Criminal_law_of_Canada" title="Criminal law of Canada">Criminal law</a> is solely a federal responsibility and is uniform throughout Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup> Law enforcement, including criminal courts, is officially a provincial responsibility, conducted by provincial and municipal police forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup> In most rural and some urban areas, policing responsibilities are contracted to the federal <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mounted_Police" title="Royal Canadian Mounted Police">Royal Canadian Mounted Police</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Canadian_Aboriginal_law" title="Canadian Aboriginal law">Canadian Aboriginal law</a> provides certain <a href="/wiki/Aboriginal_land_title_in_Canada" title="Aboriginal land title in Canada">constitutionally recognized rights to land</a> and traditional practices for Indigenous groups in Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reynolds2015_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reynolds2015-210">[209]</a></sup> Various treaties and case laws were established to mediate relations between Europeans and many Indigenous peoples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FN_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FN-211">[210]</a></sup> Most notably, a series of eleven treaties known as the <a href="/wiki/Numbered_Treaties" title="Numbered Treaties">Numbered Treaties</a> were signed between the Indigenous peoples and the reigning monarch of Canada between 1871 and 1921.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup> These treaties are agreements between the Canadian <a href="/wiki/King-in-Council" title="King-in-Council">Crown-in-Council</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Duty_to_consult_and_accommodate" title="Duty to consult and accommodate">duty to consult and accommodate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Isaac2012_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-Isaac2012-213">[212]</a></sup> The role of Aboriginal law and the rights they support were reaffirmed by <a href="/wiki/Section_35_of_the_Constitution_Act,_1982" title="Section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982">section 35 of the <i>Constitution Act, 1982</i></a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FN_211-1"><a href="#cite_note-FN-211">[210]</a></sup> These rights may include provision of services, such as health care through the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Health_Transfer_Policy" title="Indian Health Transfer Policy">Indian Health Transfer Policy</a>, and exemption from taxation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations_and_military">Foreign relations and military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Canada" title="Foreign relations of Canada">Foreign relations of Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Armed_Forces" title="Canadian Armed Forces">Canadian Armed Forces</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Canada" title="Military history of Canada">Military history of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg"><img alt="Canadian Delegation to the United Nations seated around conference table" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="560" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg/220px-Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg/330px-Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg/440px-Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Public_Domain_Image_of_Canadian_UN_delegation.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Canadian delegation to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_International_Organization" title="United Nations Conference on International Organization">United Nations Conference on International Organization</a>, San Francisco, May 1945</div></div></div>
<p>Canada is recognized as a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> for its role in international affairs with a tendency to pursue <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateral</a> solutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapnick2011a_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chapnick2011a-215">[214]</a></sup> Canada's foreign policy based on international peacekeeping and security is carried out through coalitions and international organizations, and through the work of numerous federal institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SensStoett2013a_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-SensStoett2013a-216">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadian_peacekeeping" title="Canadian peacekeeping">Canada's peacekeeping role</a> during the 20th century has played a major role in its global image.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SorensonWood2005_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-SorensonWood2005-218">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SobelShiraev2002b_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-SobelShiraev2002b-219">[218]</a></sup> The strategy of the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Canada#Foreign_aid" title="Foreign relations of Canada">Canadian government's foreign aid policy</a> reflects an emphasis to meet the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Development_Goals" title="Millennium Development Goals">Millennium Development Goals</a>, while also providing assistance in response to foreign humanitarian crises.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada was a founding member of the United Nations and has membership in the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapnick2011a_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chapnick2011a-215">[214]</a></sup> Canada is also a member of various other international and regional organizations and forums for economic and cultural affairs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> Canada acceded to the <a href="/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Civil_and_Political_Rights" title="International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights">International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights</a> in 1976.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clément2016_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-Clément2016-222">[221]</a></sup> Canada joined the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a> (OAS) in 1990 and hosted the OAS General Assembly in 2000 and the <a href="/wiki/3rd_Summit_of_the_Americas" title="3rd Summit of the Americas">3rd Summit of the Americas</a> in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup> Canada seeks to expand its ties to <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Rim" title="Pacific Rim">Pacific Rim</a> economies through membership in the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum (APEC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Canada–United States relations">Canada and the United States</a> share the world's longest undefended border, co-operate on military campaigns and exercises, and are each other's <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_trade_relations" title="Canada–United States trade relations">largest trading partner</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup> Canada nevertheless has an independent foreign policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup> For example, it maintains full <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Cuba_relations" title="Canada–Cuba relations">relations with Cuba</a> and declined to participate in the <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">2003 invasion of Iraq</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BickertonGagnon2014_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-BickertonGagnon2014-228">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada maintains historic ties to the <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="Canada–United Kingdom relations">United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93France_relations" title="Canada–France relations">France</a> and to other former British and French colonies through Canada's membership in the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a> and the <span title="French-language text"><i lang="fr"><a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a></i></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup> Canada is noted for having a positive <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Netherlands_relations" title="Canada–Netherlands relations">relationship with the Netherlands</a>, owing, in part, to its contribution to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liberation_of_the_Netherlands" title="Liberation of the Netherlands">Dutch liberation during World War II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-netherlands_93-1"><a href="#cite_note-netherlands-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada's strong attachment to the British Empire and Commonwealth led to major participation in British military efforts in the <a href="/wiki/Second_Boer_War" title="Second Boer War">Second Boer War</a> (1899–1902), World War I (1914–1918) and World War II (1939–1945).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeRouen_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouen-230">[229]</a></sup> Since then, Canada has been an advocate for multilateralism, making efforts to resolve global issues in collaboration with other nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Canada_in_the_Cold_War" title="Canada in the Cold War">Cold War</a>, Canada was a major contributor to UN forces in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> and founded the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_American_Aerospace_Defense_Command" title="North American Aerospace Defense Command">North American Aerospace Defense Command</a> (NORAD) in cooperation with the United States to defend against potential aerial attacks from the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg"><img alt="A fighter jet taking off from a runway" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="904" data-file-width="1295" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg/220px-CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg/330px-CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg/440px-CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CF-18_Cold_Lake_Alberta.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Canadian <a href="/wiki/McDonnell_Douglas_CF-18_Hornet" title="McDonnell Douglas CF-18 Hornet">McDonnell Douglas CF-18 Hornet</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cold_Lake,_Alberta" title="Cold Lake, Alberta">Cold Lake, Alberta</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a> of 1956, future prime minister <a href="/wiki/Lester_B._Pearson" title="Lester B. Pearson">Lester B. Pearson</a> eased tensions by proposing the inception of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping" title="United Nations peacekeeping">United Nations Peacekeeping Force</a>, for which he was awarded the 1957 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[233]</a></sup> As this was the first UN peacekeeping mission, Pearson is often credited as the inventor of the concept.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mays2010_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mays2010-235">[234]</a></sup> Canada has since served in over 50 peacekeeping missions, including every UN peacekeeping effort until 1989,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-morton-milhist_86-5"><a href="#cite_note-morton-milhist-86">[86]</a></sup> and has since maintained forces in international missions in <a href="/wiki/Rwanda" title="Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, the former <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, and elsewhere; Canada has sometimes faced controversy over its involvement in foreign countries, notably in the 1993 <a href="/wiki/Somalia_affair" title="Somalia affair">Somalia affair</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2001, Canada <a href="/wiki/Canada_in_the_War_in_Afghanistan" title="Canada in the War in Afghanistan">deployed troops to Afghanistan</a> as part of the U.S. stabilization force and the UN-authorized, NATO-led <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KlassenAlbo2013_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-KlassenAlbo2013-237">[236]</a></sup> In August 2007, Canada's <a href="/wiki/Territorial_claims_in_the_Arctic" title="Territorial claims in the Arctic">territorial claims in the Arctic</a> were challenged after a <a href="/wiki/Arktika_2007" title="Arktika 2007">Russian underwater expedition</a> to the <a href="/wiki/North_Pole" title="North Pole">North Pole</a>; Canada has considered that area to be sovereign territory since 1925.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup>
</p><p>The nation employs a professional, volunteer military force of approximately 79,000 active personnel and 32,250 reserve personnel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[238]</a></sup> The unified <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadian_Forces" title="Canadian Forces">Canadian Forces</a> (CF) comprise the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Army" title="Canadian Army">Canadian Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Navy" title="Royal Canadian Navy">Royal Canadian Navy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Air_Force" title="Royal Canadian Air Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a>. In 2013, Canada's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">military expenditure</a> totalled approximately $19 billion, or around one percent of the country's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup> Following the 2016 Defence Policy Review, called "<a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Strong,_Secure_and_Engaged&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Strong, Secure and Engaged (page does not exist)">Strong, Secure and Engaged</a>", the Canadian government announced a 70 percent increase to the country's defence budget over the next decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup> The Canadian Forces will acquire 88 fighter planes and 15 naval surface combatants based on the <a href="/wiki/Type_26_frigate" title="Type 26 frigate">Type 26 frigate</a> design, the latter as part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Shipbuilding_Procurement_Strategy" title="National Shipbuilding Procurement Strategy">National Shipbuilding Procurement Strategy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> Canada's total military expenditure is expected to reach $32.7 billion by 2027.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup> Canada's military currently has over 3000 personnel <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_military_operations" title="List of Canadian military operations">deployed</a> overseas, including in <a href="/wiki/Operation_Impact" title="Operation Impact">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Operation_Unifier" title="Operation Unifier">Ukraine</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Caribbe" title="Operation Caribbe">Caribbean Sea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Provinces_and_territories">Provinces and territories</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada" title="Provinces and territories of Canada">Provinces and territories of Canada</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Canadian_federalism" title="Canadian federalism">Canadian federalism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a href="/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada" title="Provinces and territories of Canada"><img alt="Labelled map of Canada detailing its provinces and territories" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="920" data-file-width="1130" decoding="async" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Political_map_of_Canada.svg/310px-Political_map_of_Canada.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Political_map_of_Canada.svg/465px-Political_map_of_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Political_map_of_Canada.svg/620px-Political_map_of_Canada.svg.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Political_map_of_Canada.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Political map of Canada showing its 10 provinces and 3 territories</div></div></div>
<p>Canada is a federation composed of ten provinces and three <a href="/wiki/Territory" title="Territory">territories</a>. In turn, these may be grouped into <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_of_Canada" title="List of regions of Canada">four main regions</a>: <a href="/wiki/Western_Canada" title="Western Canada">Western Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Canada" title="Central Canada">Central Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Canada" title="Atlantic Canada">Atlantic Canada</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Canada" title="Northern Canada">Northern Canada</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Canada" title="Eastern Canada">Eastern Canada</a></i> refers to Central Canada and Atlantic Canada together).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HamelKeil2015_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-HamelKeil2015-247">[246]</a></sup> Provinces and territories have responsibility for social programs such as <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Canada" title="Healthcare in Canada">health care</a>, <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Canada" title="Education in Canada">education</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Social_programs_in_Canada" title="Social programs in Canada">welfare</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup> as well as administration of justice (but not criminal law). Together, the provinces collect more revenue than the federal government, an almost unique structure among federations in the world. Using its spending powers, the federal government can initiate national policies in provincial areas, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Canada_Health_Act" title="Canada Health Act">Canada Health Act</a></i>; the provinces can opt out of these, but rarely do so in practice. <a href="/wiki/Equalization_payments" title="Equalization payments">Equalization payments</a> are made by the federal government to ensure reasonably uniform standards of services and taxation are kept between the richer and poorer provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup>
</p><p>The major difference between a Canadian province and a territory is that provinces receive their power and authority from the <i>Constitution Act, 1867</i>, whereas territorial governments have powers delegated to them by the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada" title="Parliament of Canada">Parliament of Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OliverMacklem2017a_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-OliverMacklem2017a-250">[249]</a></sup> The powers flowing from the <i>Constitution Act, 1867</i> are divided between the federal government and the provincial governments to exercise exclusively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meligrana2004_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-Meligrana2004-251">[250]</a></sup> As the division of powers between the federal government and the provinces is defined in the constitution, any changes require a <a href="/wiki/Amendments_to_the_Constitution_of_Canada" title="Amendments to the Constitution of Canada">constitutional amendment</a>. The territories being creatures of the federal government, changes to their role and division of powers may be performed unilaterally by the Parliament of Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nicholson1979_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nicholson1979-252">[251]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Canada" title="Economy of Canada">Economy of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1365" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg/240px-Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg/360px-Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg/480px-Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Toronto_from_above_at_night.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_Toronto" title="Financial District, Toronto">Toronto financial district</a> is the second-largest financial centre in North America, the seventh-largest globally in employment and the heart of Canada's finance industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sassen2018_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sassen2018-253">[252]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Canada has a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">highly developed</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mixed-market" title="Mixed-market">mixed-market economy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[254]</a></sup> with the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">eighth-largest economy</a> as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> of approximately US$2.221 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_IMF_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-GDP_IMF-256">[255]</a></sup> It is one of the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">least corrupt countries in the world</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RotbergCarment2018_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-RotbergCarment2018-257">[256]</a></sup> and is one of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Trading_nation" title="Trading nation">trading nations</a>, with a highly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Globalized" title="Globalized">globalized</a> economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup> Canada mixed economy ranks above the U.S. and most western European nations on <a href="/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation" title="The Heritage Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">Index of Economic Freedom</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[258]</a></sup> and experiencing a relatively low level of <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">income disparity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-databook2018_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-databook2018-260">[259]</a></sup> The country's average household <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Disposable_income" title="Disposable income">disposable income</a> per capita is "well above" the OECD average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Toronto_Stock_Exchange" title="Toronto Stock Exchange">Toronto Stock Exchange</a> is the ninth-largest <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchange</a> in the world by <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a>, listing over 1,500 companies with a combined market capitalization of over US$2 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, Canadian trade in goods and services reached $2.016 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-econ-263">[262]</a></sup> Canada's exports totalled over $637 billion, while its imported goods were worth over $631 billion, of which approximately $391 billion originated from the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ_263-1"><a href="#cite_note-econ-263">[262]</a></sup> In 2018, Canada had a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_deficit" title="Trade deficit">trade deficit</a> in goods of $22 billion and a trade deficit in services of $25 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ_263-2"><a href="#cite_note-econ-263">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the early 20th century, the growth of Canada's manufacturing, mining, and service sectors has transformed the nation from a largely rural economy to an urbanized, industrial one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarrisMatthews1987l_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-HarrisMatthews1987l-264">[263]</a></sup> Like many other developed countries, the Canadian economy is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service industry</a>, which employs about three-quarters of the country's workforce.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup> Among developed countries, Canada has an unusually important <a href="/wiki/Primary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Primary sector of the economy">primary sector</a>, of which the <a href="/wiki/Forestry_in_Canada" title="Forestry in Canada">forestry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Canada" title="Petroleum industry in Canada">petroleum industries</a> are the most prominent components.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SueyoshiGoto2018_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-SueyoshiGoto2018-266">[265]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FTAs_with_Canada.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="566" data-file-width="1104" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/FTAs_with_Canada.svg/260px-FTAs_with_Canada.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/FTAs_with_Canada.svg/390px-FTAs_with_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/FTAs_with_Canada.svg/520px-FTAs_with_Canada.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FTAs_with_Canada.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#000; color:white;"> </span> Canada</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#393; color:black;"> </span> Countries and territories with free-trade agreements</div></div></div></div>
<p>Canada's economic integration with the United States has increased significantly since <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Automotive_Products_Trade_Agreement" title="Automotive Products Trade Agreement">Automotive Products Trade Agreement</a> of 1965 opened Canada's borders to trade in the automobile manufacturing industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KerrPerdikis2014_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-KerrPerdikis2014-268">[267]</a></sup> In the 1970s, concerns over energy self-sufficiency and foreign ownership in the manufacturing sectors prompted Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau" title="Pierre Trudeau">Pierre Trudeau</a>'s Liberal government to enact the <a href="/wiki/National_Energy_Program" title="National Energy Program">National Energy Program</a> (NEP) and the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Investment_Review_Agency" title="Foreign Investment Review Agency">Foreign Investment Review Agency</a> (FIRA).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup> In the 1980s, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Brian_Mulroney" title="Brian Mulroney">Brian Mulroney</a>'s Progressive Conservatives abolished the NEP and changed the name of FIRA to <a href="/wiki/Invest_in_Canada" title="Invest in Canada">Investment Canada</a>, to encourage foreign investment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canada_%E2%80%93_United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Canada – United States Free Trade Agreement">Canada – United States Free Trade Agreement</a> (FTA) of 1988 eliminated tariffs between the two countries, while the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">North American Free Trade Agreement</a> (NAFTA) expanded the free-trade zone to include <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a> in 1994 (later replaced by the <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement" title="United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement">Canada–United States–Mexico Agreement</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nzongola-NtalajaKrieger2001_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nzongola-NtalajaKrieger2001-271">[270]</a></sup> Canada has a strong <a href="/wiki/Cooperative_banking" title="Cooperative banking">cooperative banking</a> sector, with the world's highest per-capita membership in <a href="/wiki/Credit_union" title="Credit union">credit unions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KobrakMartin2018_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-KobrakMartin2018-272">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada is one of the few developed nations that are net exporters of energy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SueyoshiGoto2018_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-SueyoshiGoto2018-266">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-energy_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-energy-273">[272]</a></sup> Atlantic Canada possesses vast <a href="/wiki/Offshore_drilling" title="Offshore drilling">offshore</a> deposits of natural gas, and Alberta also hosts large oil and gas resources. The vastness of the <a href="/wiki/Athabasca_oil_sands" title="Athabasca oil sands">Athabasca oil sands</a> and other assets results in Canada having a 13 percent share of global <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a>, comprising the world's third-largest share after <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves_in_Venezuela" title="Oil reserves in Venezuela">Venezuela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves_in_Saudi_Arabia" title="Oil reserves in Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lopez-Vallejo2016_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lopez-Vallejo2016-274">[273]</a></sup> Canada is additionally one of the world's largest suppliers of agricultural products; the Canadian Prairies are one of the most important global producers of wheat, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canola" title="Canola">canola</a>, and other grains.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup> The federal <a href="/wiki/Natural_Resources_Canada" title="Natural Resources Canada">Department of Natural Resources</a> provides statistics regarding its major exports; the country is a leading exporter of <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">nickel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Platinum_group" title="Platinum group">platinoids</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aluminum" title="Aluminum">aluminum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coking_coal" title="Coking coal">coking coal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Molybdenum" title="Molybdenum">molybdenum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cobalt" title="Cobalt">cobalt</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cadmium" title="Cadmium">cadmium</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haldar2016_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haldar2016-276">[275]</a></sup> Many towns in northern Canada, where agriculture is difficult, are sustainable because of nearby mines or sources of timber. Canada also has a sizeable manufacturing sector centred in southern Ontario and Quebec, with automobiles and <a href="/wiki/Aeronautics" title="Aeronautics">aeronautics</a> representing particularly important industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[276]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Canada" title="Science and technology in Canada">Science and technology in Canada</a></div>
<p>In 2019, Canada spent approximately $40.3 billion on domestic <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a>, of which over $7 billion was provided by the federal and provincial governments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[277]</a></sup> As of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country has produced fifteen <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">Nobel laureates</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">chemistry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">medicine</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[278]</a></sup> and was ranked fourth worldwide for scientific research quality in a major 2012 survey of international scientists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[279]</a></sup> It is furthermore home to the headquarters of a number of global technology firms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup> Canada <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">has one of the highest levels of Internet access in the world</a>, with over 33 million users, equivalent to around 94 percent of its total 2014 population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup> Canada was ranked 16th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021 and 17th in 2019 and 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_(NASA_S116-E-05765).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3032" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_%28NASA_S116-E-05765%29.jpg/220px-STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_%28NASA_S116-E-05765%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_%28NASA_S116-E-05765%29.jpg/330px-STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_%28NASA_S116-E-05765%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_%28NASA_S116-E-05765%29.jpg/440px-STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_%28NASA_S116-E-05765%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:STS-116_-_P5_Truss_hand-off_to_ISS_(NASA_S116-E-05765).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Canadian-built <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a> robotic arm (left), referred to as <a href="/wiki/Canadarm" title="Canadarm">Canadarm</a>, transferred the <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Truss_Structure" title="Integrated Truss Structure">P5 truss segment</a> over to the Canadian-built <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> robotic arm, referred to as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadarm2" title="Canadarm2">Canadarm2</a></div></div></div>
<p>Some of the most notable scientific developments in Canada include the creation of the modern <a href="/wiki/Alkaline_battery" title="Alkaline battery">alkaline battery</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Insulin" title="Insulin">Insulin</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yale_University_Press_1999_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-Yale_University_Press_1999-287">[286]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Polio_vaccine" title="Polio vaccine">polio vaccine</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Farrell_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-Farrell-288">[287]</a></sup> and discoveries about the interior structure of the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_nucleus" title="Atomic nucleus">atomic nucleus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Katz_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-Katz-289">[288]</a></sup> Other major Canadian scientific contributions include the <a href="/wiki/Artificial_cardiac_pacemaker" title="Artificial cardiac pacemaker">artificial cardiac pacemaker</a>, mapping the <a href="/wiki/Visual_cortex" title="Visual cortex">visual cortex</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-topten_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-topten-291">[290]</a></sup> the development of the <a href="/wiki/Electron_microscope" title="Electron microscope">electron microscope</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">plate tectonics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning" title="Deep learning">deep learning</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multi-touch" title="Multi-touch">multi-touch</a> technology and the identification of the first <a href="/wiki/Black_hole" title="Black hole">black hole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cygnus_X-1" title="Cygnus X-1">Cygnus X-1</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> Canada has a long history of discovery in genetics, which include <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell" title="Stem cell">stem cells</a>, <a href="/wiki/Site-directed_mutagenesis" title="Site-directed mutagenesis">site-directed mutagenesis</a>, <a href="/wiki/T-cell_receptor" title="T-cell receptor">T-cell receptor</a> and the identification of the genes that cause <a href="/wiki/Fanconi_anemia" title="Fanconi anemia">Fanconi anemia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cystic_fibrosis" title="Cystic fibrosis">cystic fibrosis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Early-onset_Alzheimer%27s_disease" title="Early-onset Alzheimer's disease">early-onset Alzheimer's disease</a>, among numerous other diseases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-topten_291-1"><a href="#cite_note-topten-291">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Space_Agency" title="Canadian Space Agency">Canadian Space Agency</a> operates a highly active space program, conducting deep-space, planetary, and aviation research, and developing rockets and satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[295]</a></sup> Canada was the third country to design and construct a satellite after the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviet Union</a> and the United States, with the 1962 <a href="/wiki/Alouette_1" title="Alouette 1">Alouette 1</a> launch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Angelo2009s_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-Angelo2009s-297">[296]</a></sup> Canada is a participant in the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> (ISS), and is a pioneer in space robotics, having constructed the <a href="/wiki/Canadarm" title="Canadarm">Canadarm</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadarm2" title="Canadarm2">Canadarm2</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dextre" title="Dextre">Dextre</a> robotic manipulators for the ISS and NASA's <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bidaud2012_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bidaud2012-298">[297]</a></sup> Since the 1960s, Canada's aerospace industry has designed and built numerous marques of satellite, including <a href="/wiki/Radarsat-1" title="Radarsat-1">Radarsat-1</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radarsat-2" title="Radarsat-2">2</a>, <a href="/wiki/ISIS_(satellite)" title="ISIS (satellite)">ISIS</a> and <a href="/wiki/MOST_(spacecraft)" title="MOST (spacecraft)">MOST</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> Canada has also produced one of the world's most successful and widely used <a href="/wiki/Sounding_rocket" title="Sounding rocket">sounding rockets</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Black_Brant_(rocket)" title="Black Brant (rocket)">Black Brant</a>; over 1,000 Black Brants have been launched since the rocket's introduction in 1961.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Godefroy2017_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-Godefroy2017-300">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada" title="Demographics of Canada">Demographics of Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Canada" title="List of cities in Canada">List of cities in Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg"><img alt="Two-colour map of Windsor area with towns along the St. Lawrence river" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg/220px-Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg/330px-Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg/440px-Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Quebec-Windsor_Corridor.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City%E2%80%93Windsor_Corridor" title="Quebec City–Windsor Corridor">Quebec City–Windsor Corridor</a> is the most densely populated and heavily industrialized region of Canada and spans 1,200 km (750 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McMurryShepherd2004_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-McMurryShepherd2004-301">[300]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/2021_Canadian_census" title="2021 Canadian census">2021 Canadian census</a> enumerated a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Population_of_Canada_by_year" title="Population of Canada by year">total population</a> of 36,991,981, an increase of around 5.2 percent over the 2016 figure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2021cen_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-2021cen-302">[301]</a></sup> The main drivers of population growth are <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Canada" title="Immigration to Canada">immigration</a> and, to a lesser extent, natural growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup> Canada has one of the highest per-capita immigration rates in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup> driven mainly by <a href="/wiki/Economic_impact_of_immigration_to_Canada" title="Economic impact of immigration to Canada">economic policy</a> and also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immigration_categories_(Canada)" title="Immigration categories (Canada)">family reunification</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HollifieldMartin2014_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-HollifieldMartin2014-305">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BeaujotKerr2007j_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-BeaujotKerr2007j-306">[305]</a></sup> A record number of 405,000 immigrants were admitted to Canada in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup> New immigrants settle mostly in <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_largest_population_centres_in_Canada" title="List of the largest population centres in Canada">major urban areas in the country</a>, such as Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup> Canada also accepts large numbers of refugees, accounting for over 10 percent of annual global <a href="/wiki/Third_country_resettlement" title="Third country resettlement">refugee resettlements</a>; it resettled more than 28,000 in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada's population density, at 4.2 inhabitants per square kilometre (11/sq mi), is among the lowest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2021cen_302-1"><a href="#cite_note-2021cen-302">[301]</a></sup> Canada spans latitudinally from the 83rd parallel north to the 41st parallel north, and approximately 95 percent of the population is found south of the 55th parallel north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD2014_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2014-311">[310]</a></sup> About four-fifths of the population lives within 150 kilometres (93 mi) of the border with the contiguous United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup> The most densely populated part of the country, accounting for nearly 50 percent, is the <a href="/wiki/Quebec_City%E2%80%93Windsor_Corridor" title="Quebec City–Windsor Corridor">Quebec City–Windsor Corridor</a> in Southern Quebec and Southern Ontario along the Great Lakes and the Saint Lawrence River.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McMurryShepherd2004_301-1"><a href="#cite_note-McMurryShepherd2004-301">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD2014_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2014-311">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>The majority of Canadians (81.1 percent) live in family households, 12.1 percent report living alone, and those living with other relatives or unrelated persons reported at 6.8  percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-profile21_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-profile21-313">[312]</a></sup> Fifty-one percent of households are couples with or without children, 8.7% are single-parent households, 2.9% are multigenerational households, and 29.3% are single-person households.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-profile21_313-1"><a href="#cite_note-profile21-313">[312]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Canada" title="Healthcare in Canada">Healthcare in Canada</a></div>
