<p>Healthcare in Canada is delivered through the provincial and territorial systems of <a href="/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care" title="Publicly funded health care">publicly funded health care</a>, informally called Medicare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AaseWaring2017_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-AaseWaring2017-314">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[314]</a></sup> It is guided by the provisions of the <i><a href="/wiki/Canada_Health_Act" title="Canada Health Act">Canada Health Act</a></i> of 1984,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bégin1988_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bégin1988-316">[315]</a></sup> and is <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LeattMapa2003_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-LeattMapa2003-317">[316]</a></sup> Universal access to publicly funded health services "is often considered by Canadians as a fundamental value that ensures national health care insurance for everyone wherever they live in the country."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[317]</a></sup> Around 30 percent of Canadians' healthcare is paid for through the private sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kroll2012_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kroll2012-319">[318]</a></sup> This mostly pays for services not covered or partially covered by Medicare, such as <a href="/wiki/Prescription_drug" title="Prescription drug">prescription drugs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dentistry" title="Dentistry">dentistry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Optometry" title="Optometry">optometry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kroll2012_319-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kroll2012-319">[318]</a></sup> Approximately 65 to 75 percent of Canadians have some form of supplementary health insurance related to the aforementioned reasons; many receive it through their employers or utilizes secondary social service programs related to extended coverage for families receiving social assistance or vulnerable demographics, such as seniors, minors, and those with disabilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chen2018_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chen2018-320">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kroll2012_319-2"><a href="#cite_note-Kroll2012-319">[318]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Health_care_cost_rise.svg"><img alt="graph of expenditures as described in the caption" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="440" data-file-width="750" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Health_care_cost_rise.svg/290px-Health_care_cost_rise.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Health_care_cost_rise.svg/435px-Health_care_cost_rise.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Health_care_cost_rise.svg/580px-Health_care_cost_rise.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Health_care_cost_rise.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Health care cost rise based on total expenditure on health as percent of GDP. Countries shown are the United States, Germany, Austria, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, and Canada.</div></div></div>
<p>In common with many other developed countries, Canada is experiencing a cost increase due to a <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">demographic shift</a> toward an older population, with more retirees and fewer people of working age. In 2006, the average age was 39.5 years;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup> it rose to 42.4 years by 2018<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia-322">[321]</a></sup> before falling slightly to 41.9 in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-profile21_313-2"><a href="#cite_note-profile21-313">[312]</a></sup> Life expectancy is 81.1 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup> A 2016 report by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Public_Health_Officer_of_Canada" title="Chief Public Health Officer of Canada">chief public health officer</a> found that 88 percent of Canadians, one of the highest proportions of the population among G7 countries, indicated that they "had good or very good health".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[323]</a></sup> Eighty percent of Canadian adults self-report having at least one major risk factor for chronic disease: smoking, physical inactivity, unhealthy eating or excessive alcohol use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GregoryStephens2019_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-GregoryStephens2019-325">[324]</a></sup> Canada has one of the highest rates of adult obesity among Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (<a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>) countries attributing to approximately 2.7 million cases of <a href="/wiki/Diabetes" title="Diabetes">diabetes</a> (types 1 and 2 combined).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GregoryStephens2019_325-1"><a href="#cite_note-GregoryStephens2019-325">[324]</a></sup> Four chronic diseases—<a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancer</a> (leading cause of death), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" title="Cardiovascular diseases">cardiovascular diseases</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Respiratory_diseases" title="Respiratory diseases">respiratory diseases</a> and diabetes—account for 65 percent of deaths in Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Institute_for_Health_Information" title="Canadian Institute for Health Information">Canadian Institute for Health Information</a> reported that healthcare spending reached $308<span class="nowrap"> </span>billion, or 12.7 percent of Canada's GDP for that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup> Canada's per-capita spending on health expenditures ranked 4th among <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_health_expenditure_per_capita" title="List of countries by total health expenditure per capita">health-care systems in the OECD</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[328]</a></sup> Canada has performed close to, or above the average on the majority of OECD health indicators since the early 2000s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[329]</a></sup> Although Canada consistently ranks above the average on OECD indicators for wait-times and access to care, with average scores for quality of care and use of resources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Fund" title="Commonwealth Fund">Commonwealth Funds</a> 2021 report comparing the healthcare systems of the 11 most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developed_countries" title="Developed countries">developed countries</a> ranked Canada second -to-last.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-commonwealthfund_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-commonwealthfund-332">[331]</a></sup> Identified weaknesses were comparatively higher infant mortality rate, the prevalence of chronic conditions, long wait times, poor availability of after-hours care, and a lack of prescription drugs and dental coverage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-commonwealthfund_332-1"><a href="#cite_note-commonwealthfund-332">[331]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Canada" title="Education in Canada">Education in Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Canada" title="Higher education in Canada">Higher education in Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:14th_G7_summit.jpg"><img alt="portrait of the group of named world leaders" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2316" data-file-width="2988" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/14th_G7_summit.jpg/220px-14th_G7_summit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/14th_G7_summit.jpg/330px-14th_G7_summit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/14th_G7_summit.jpg/440px-14th_G7_summit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:14th_G7_summit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/14th_G7_summit" title="14th G7 summit">14th G7 summit</a> leaders at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Toronto" title="University of Toronto">University of Toronto</a>: (left to right) <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Delors" title="Jacques Delors">Jacques Delors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ciriaco_De_Mita" title="Ciriaco De Mita">Ciriaco De Mita</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher" title="Margaret Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brian_Mulroney" title="Brian Mulroney">Brian Mulroney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="François Mitterrand">François Mitterrand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helmut_Kohl" title="Helmut Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Noboru_Takeshita" title="Noboru Takeshita">Noboru Takeshita</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Canada" title="Education in Canada">Education in Canada</a> is for the most part provided <a href="/wiki/State_school" title="State school">publicly</a>, funded and overseen by <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">federal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada" title="Provinces and territories of Canada">provincial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Local_government" title="Local government">local governments</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015_federal_budget_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-2015_federal_budget-333">[332]</a></sup> Education is within provincial jurisdiction and the curriculum is overseen by the province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MontesinosVela2013_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-MontesinosVela2013-335">[334]</a></sup> Education in Canada is generally divided into <a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">primary education</a>, followed by secondary education and post-secondary. Education in both English and French is available in most places across Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Epstein2008_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-Epstein2008-336">[335]</a></sup> Canada has a large number of universities, almost all of which are publicly funded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ShanahanNilson2016_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-ShanahanNilson2016-337">[336]</a></sup> Established in 1663, <a href="/wiki/Universit%C3%A9_Laval" title="Université Laval">Université Laval</a> is the oldest <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Canada" title="Higher education in Canada">post-secondary institution in Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BlakeKeshen2017p249_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-BlakeKeshen2017p249-338">[337]</a></sup> The largest university is the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Toronto" title="University of Toronto">University of Toronto</a> with over 85,000 students.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Richards2019_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-Richards2019-339">[338]</a></sup> Four universities are regularly ranked among the top 100 world-wide, namely University of Toronto, <a href="/wiki/University_of_British_Columbia" title="University of British Columbia">University of British Columbia</a>, <a href="/wiki/McGill_University" title="McGill University">McGill University</a> and <a href="/wiki/McMaster_University" title="McMaster University">McMaster University</a>, with a total of <a href="/wiki/Rankings_of_universities_in_Canada" title="Rankings of universities in Canada">18 universities ranked</a> in the top 500 worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARWU2019|_Canada_Universities_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-ARWU2019|_Canada_Universities-340">[339]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a 2019 report by the OECD, Canada is one of the most educated countries in the world;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-world_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-world-341">[340]</a></sup> the country ranks first worldwide in the number of adults having <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary education</a>, with over 56 percent of Canadian adults having attained at least an undergraduate college or university degree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-world_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-world-341">[340]</a></sup> Canada spends about 5.3 percent of its GDP on education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[341]</a></sup> The country invests heavily in tertiary education (more than US$20,000 per student).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 89 percent of adults aged 25 to 64 have earned the equivalent of a high-school degree, compared to an OECD average of 75 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECDBLI2_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECDBLI2-344">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">mandatory education</a> age ranges between 5–7 to 16–18 years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup> contributing to an adult literacy rate of 99 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_322-1"><a href="#cite_note-cia-322">[321]</a></sup> Just over 60,000 children are <a href="/wiki/Homeschooling_in_Canada" title="Homeschooling in Canada">homeschooled in the country</a> as of 2016. The <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> indicates Canadian students perform well above the OECD average, particularly in mathematics, science, and reading,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup> ranking the overall knowledge and skills of Canadian 15-year-olds as the sixth-best in the world, although these scores have been declining in recent years. Canada is a well-performing OECD country in reading literacy, mathematics, and science with the average student scoring 523.7, compared with the OECD average of 493 in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicity">Ethnicity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canadians" title="Canadians">Canadians</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Censusdivisions-ethnic.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1214" data-file-width="1388" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Censusdivisions-ethnic.png/240px-Censusdivisions-ethnic.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Censusdivisions-ethnic.png/360px-Censusdivisions-ethnic.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Censusdivisions-ethnic.png/480px-Censusdivisions-ethnic.png 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Censusdivisions-ethnic.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the dominant self-identified ethnic origins per census division of 2006<div> <table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;"> <tbody><tr> <td style="width: 50%;text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF2400; color:black;"> </span> Canadian<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canadian_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-Canadian-350">[b]</a></sup></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF9999; color:black;"> </span> English</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#273BE2; color:white;"> </span> French</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#7DF9FF; color:black;"> </span> Scottish</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFFF00; color:black;"> </span> German</div> </td> <td style="width: 50%;text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#228B22; color:black;"> </span> Italian</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#7B3F00; color:white;"> </span> First Nations</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#008080; color:white;"> </span> Ukrainian </div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF9933; color:black;"> </span> Indian</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF00FF; color:black;"> </span> Inuit</div> </td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></div>
<p>According to the 2016 Canadian Census, over 250 "ethnic or cultural origins" were self-reported by Canadians, with four out of ten people reporting more than one origin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[349]</a></sup> 20 million or 72.9 percent of the population report having <a href="/wiki/European_Canadians" title="European Canadians">European</a> descent, followed by <a href="/wiki/Asian_Canadians" title="Asian Canadians">Asian</a> (17.7 percent), <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Canada" title="Indigenous peoples in Canada">Indigenous</a> (4.9 percent), African (3.1 percent), <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Canadians" title="Latin American Canadians">Latin American</a> (1.3 percent), and <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceanian</a> ( 0.2 percent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_origins_of_people_in_Canada" title="Ethnic origins of people in Canada">country's largest self-reported group</a> is Canadian<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canadian_350-1"><a href="#cite_note-Canadian-350">[b]</a></sup> (accounting for 32 percent of the population), followed by <a href="/wiki/English_Canadians" title="English Canadians">English</a> (18.3 percent), <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Canadians" title="Scottish Canadians">Scottish</a> (13.9 percent), French (13.6 percent), <a href="/wiki/Irish_Canadians" title="Irish Canadians">Irish</a> (13.4 percent), <a href="/wiki/German_Canadians" title="German Canadians">German</a> (9.6 percent), <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Canadians" title="Chinese Canadians">Chinese</a> (5.1 percent), <a href="/wiki/Italian_Canadians" title="Italian Canadians">Italian</a> (4.6 percent), First Nations (4.4 percent), <a href="/wiki/Indo-Canadians" title="Indo-Canadians">Indian</a> (4.0 percent), and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Canadians" title="Ukrainian Canadians">Ukrainian</a> (3.9 percent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity-356">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 2006 to 2016, the Indigenous population has grown by 42.5 percent, four times the national rate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup> 22.3 percent of the population belonged to a non-Indigenous <a href="/wiki/Visible_minority" title="Visible minority">visible minority</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[c]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census_Profile,_2016_Census_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-Census_Profile,_2016_Census-360">[357]</a></sup> In 2016, the largest visible minority groups were <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Canadians" title="South Asian Canadians">South Asian</a> (5.6 percent), Chinese (5.1 percent) and <a href="/wiki/Black_Canadians" title="Black Canadians">Black</a> (3.5 percent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census_Profile,_2016_Census_360-1"><a href="#cite_note-Census_Profile,_2016_Census-360">[357]</a></sup> Between 2011 and 2016, the visible minority population rose by 18.4 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census_Profile,_2016_Census_360-2"><a href="#cite_note-Census_Profile,_2016_Census-360">[357]</a></sup> In 1961, less than two percent of Canada's population (about 300,000 people) were members of visible minority groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[358]</a></sup> The 2016 Census indicated that 21.9 percent of the Canadian population reported themselves as being or having been a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_residency_in_Canada" title="Permanent residency in Canada">landed immigrant or permanent resident</a> in Canada—close to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1921_Canadian_Census" title="1921 Canadian Census">1921 Census</a> record of 22.3 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StatCanCultDivers2017_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-StatCanCultDivers2017-362">[359]</a></sup> In 2021 India, China, and the Philippines were the top three countries of origin for immigrants moving to Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[360]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Canada" title="Languages of Canada">Languages of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg"><img alt="Map of Canada with English speakers and French speakers at a percentage" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="940" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg/240px-Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg/360px-Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg/480px-Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg.png 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bilinguisme_au_Canada-fr.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Approximately 98 percent of Canadians can speak either or both English and French:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Highlights_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-Highlights-364">[361]</a></sup><small><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFE400; color:black;"> </span> English – 56.9%</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#D8A820; color:black;"> </span> English and French – 16.1%</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#B07400; color:black;"> </span> French – 21.3%</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#F5F5DC; color:black;"> </span> Sparsely populated area ( &lt; 0.4 persons per km<sup>2</sup>)</div></small></div></div></div>
<p>A multitude of languages are used by Canadians, with <a href="/wiki/Canadian_English" title="Canadian English">English</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_French" title="Canadian French">French</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a>) being the <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">mother tongues</a> of approximately 54 percent and 19 percent of Canadians, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-365">[362]</a></sup> As of the 2021 Census, just over 7.8 million Canadians listed a non-official language as their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother-tongue" title="Mother-tongue">mother tongue</a>. Some of the most common non-official first languages include <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">Mandarin</a> (679,255 first-language speakers), <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a> (666,585), <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> (553,380), Spanish (538,870), <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> (508,410), <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a> (461,150), Italian (319,505), and German (272,865).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_365-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-365">[362]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Official_bilingualism_in_Canada" title="Official bilingualism in Canada">Canada's federal government practices official bilingualism</a>, which is applied by the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_Commissioner_of_Official_Languages" title="Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages">commissioner of official languages</a> in consonance with <a href="/wiki/Section_16_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Section 16 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms">section 16 of the <i>Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</i></a> and the federal <i><a href="/wiki/Official_Languages_Act_(Canada)" title="Official Languages Act (Canada)">Official Languages Act</a></i>. English and French have equal status in federal courts, Parliament, and in all federal institutions. Citizens have the right, where there is sufficient demand, to receive federal government services in either English or French and official-<a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">language minorities</a> are guaranteed their own schools in all provinces and territories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1977 <i><a href="/wiki/Charter_of_the_French_Language" title="Charter of the French Language">Charter of the French Language</a></i> established French as the official language of <a href="/wiki/Quebec" title="Quebec">Quebec</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[364]</a></sup> Although more than 82 percent of French-speaking Canadians live in Quebec, there are substantial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Francophone" title="Francophone">Francophone</a> populations in <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_New_Brunswick" title="Demographics of New Brunswick">New Brunswick</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franco-Albertans" title="Franco-Albertans">Alberta</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Franco-Manitoban" title="Franco-Manitoban">Manitoba</a>; <a href="/wiki/Franco-Ontarian" title="Franco-Ontarian">Ontario</a> has the largest French-speaking population outside Quebec.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Webber2015_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-Webber2015-368">[365]</a></sup> New Brunswick, the only officially bilingual province, has a French-speaking Acadian minority constituting 33 percent of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Auer2010b_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-Auer2010b-369">[366]</a></sup> There are also clusters of Acadians in southwestern Nova Scotia, on Cape Breton Island, and through central and western Prince Edward Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[367]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other provinces have no official languages as such, but French is used as a language of instruction, in courts, and for other government services, in addition to English. Manitoba, Ontario, and Quebec allow for both English and French to be spoken in the provincial legislatures, and laws are enacted in both languages. In Ontario, French has some legal status, but is not fully co-official.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[368]</a></sup> There are 11 <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Canada" title="Languages of Canada">Indigenous language groups</a>, composed of more than 65 distinct languages and dialects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[369]</a></sup> Several Indigenous languages have official status in the Northwest Territories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[370]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Inuktitut" title="Inuktitut">Inuktitut</a> is the majority language in Nunavut, and is one of three official languages in the territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[371]</a></sup>
</p><p>Additionally, Canada is home to many <a href="/wiki/Sign_language" title="Sign language">sign languages</a>, some of which are Indigenous.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[372]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/American_Sign_Language" title="American Sign Language">American Sign Language</a> (ASL) is spoken across the country due to the prevalence of ASL in primary and secondary schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JepsenClerck2015_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-JepsenClerck2015-376">[373]</a></sup> Due to its historical relation to the francophone culture, <a href="/wiki/Quebec_Sign_Language" title="Quebec Sign Language">Quebec Sign Language</a> (LSQ) is spoken primarily in Quebec, although there are sizeable Francophone communities in New Brunswick, Ontario and Manitoba.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BaileyDolby2002_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-BaileyDolby2002-377">[374]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Canada" title="Religion in Canada">Religion in Canada</a></div>
<p>Canada is religiously diverse, encompassing a wide range of beliefs and customs. Canada has no official church, and the government is officially committed to <a href="/wiki/Religious_pluralism" title="Religious pluralism">religious pluralism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moon2008_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moon2008-378">[375]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Canada" title="Freedom of religion in Canada">Freedom of religion in Canada</a> is a constitutionally protected right, allowing individuals to assemble and worship without limitation or interference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott2012n_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scott2012n-379">[376]</a></sup> The practice of religion is generally considered a private matter throughout society and the state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoyleSheen2013_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-BoyleSheen2013-380">[377]</a></sup> With <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> in decline after having once been central and integral to Canadian culture and daily life,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roberts2005w_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roberts2005w-381">[378]</a></sup> Canada has become a <a href="/wiki/Postchristianity" title="Postchristianity">post-Christian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secularity" title="Secularity">secular</a> state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BramadatSeljak2009_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-BramadatSeljak2009-382">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bowen2004_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bowen2004-383">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GregoryJohnston2009_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-GregoryJohnston2009-384">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BermanBhargava2013b_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-BermanBhargava2013b-385">[382]</a></sup> The majority of Canadians consider <a href="/wiki/Importance_of_religion_by_country" title="Importance of religion by country">religion to be unimportant</a> in their daily lives,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Punnett2015a_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-Punnett2015a-386">[383]</a></sup> but still believe in God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haskell2009_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haskell2009-387">[384]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the 2011 National Household Survey, 67.3 percent of <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Canada" title="Christianity in Canada">Canadians identify as Christian</a>; of these, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Canada" title="Catholic Church in Canada">Roman Catholics make up the largest group</a>, accounting for 38.7 percent of the population. Much of the remainder is made up of <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Canada" title="Protestantism in Canada">Canadian Protestants</a>, who accounted for approximately 27 percent in a 2011 survey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011NHSreligiondetailed_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-2011NHSreligiondetailed-388">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[386]</a></sup> The largest Protestant denomination is the <a href="/wiki/United_Church_of_Canada" title="United Church of Canada">United Church of Canada</a> (accounting for 6.1 percent of Canadians), followed by the <a href="/wiki/Anglican_Church_of_Canada" title="Anglican Church of Canada">Anglican Church of Canada</a> (5.0 percent), and <a href="/wiki/Baptists_in_Canada" title="Baptists in Canada">various Baptist sects</a> (1.9 percent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statcan1_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-statcan1-390">[387]</a></sup> Secularization has been growing since the 1960s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[389]</a></sup> In 2011, <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Canada" title="Irreligion in Canada">23.9 percent declared no religious affiliation</a>, compared to 16.5 percent in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[390]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Canada" title="Islam in Canada">Islam is the largest non-Christian religion in Canada</a>, constituting 3.2 percent of its population. It is also the fastest growing religion in Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nationalpost1_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-nationalpost1-394">[391]</a></sup> 1.5 percent of the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Canada" title="Hinduism in Canada">Canadian population is Hindu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_Canada" title="Sikhism in Canada">1.4 is Sikh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statcan1_390-1"><a href="#cite_note-statcan1-390">[387]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Canada" title="Culture of Canada">Culture of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="771" data-file-width="702" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg/170px-Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg/255px-Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg/340px-Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_outside_Union_Station.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Monument to <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_Canada" title="Multiculturalism in Canada">Multiculturalism</a></i> by Francesco Pirelli, in <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a></div></div></div>
<p>Canada's culture draws influences from its broad range of constituent nationalities, and policies that promote a "<a href="/wiki/Just_society" title="Just society">just society</a>" are constitutionally protected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LaSelva1996k_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-LaSelva1996k-395">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newman2012_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-Newman2012-397">[394]</a></sup> Canada has placed emphasis on equality and inclusiveness for all its people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GuoWong2015_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-GuoWong2015-398">[395]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_Canada" title="Multiculturalism in Canada">The official state policy of multiculturalism</a> is often cited as one of Canada's significant accomplishments,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sikka2014v_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sikka2014v-399">[396]</a></sup> and a key distinguishing element of Canadian identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JohnsonJoseph-Salisbury2018_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-JohnsonJoseph-Salisbury2018-400">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Caplow2001a_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-Caplow2001a-401">[398]</a></sup> In Quebec, cultural identity is strong, and there is a <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Quebec" title="Culture of Quebec">French Canadian culture</a> that is distinct from English Canadian culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[399]</a></sup> As a whole, Canada is in theory a <a href="/wiki/Cultural_mosaic" title="Cultural mosaic">cultural mosaic</a> of regional ethnic subcultures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[400]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada's approach to governance emphasizing multiculturalism, which is based on selective <a href="/wiki/Economic_migrant" title="Economic migrant">immigration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_integration" title="Social integration">social integration</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dissent" title="Dissent">suppression</a> of far-right politics, has wide public support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ambrosea_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ambrosea-404">[401]</a></sup> Government policies such as publicly funded health care, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Income_taxes_in_Canada" title="Income taxes in Canada">higher taxation</a> to redistribute wealth, the <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Canada" title="Capital punishment in Canada">outlawing of capital punishment</a>, strong efforts to <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Canada" title="Poverty in Canada">eliminate poverty</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gun_politics_in_Canada" title="Gun politics in Canada">strict gun control</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_liberal" title="Social liberal">social liberal</a> attitude toward <a href="/wiki/Feminism_in_Canada" title="Feminism in Canada">women's rights</a> (like <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_Canada" title="Abortion in Canada">pregnancy termination</a>) and <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Canada" title="LGBT rights in Canada">LGBTQ rights</a>, legalized <a href="/wiki/Euthanasia_in_Canada" title="Euthanasia in Canada">euthanasia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_in_Canada" title="Cannabis in Canada">cannabis use</a> are indicators of Canada's political and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_values" title="Canadian values">cultural values</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HollifieldMartin2014b_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-HollifieldMartin2014b-405">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[404]</a></sup> Canadians also identify with the country's foreign aid policies, peacekeeping roles, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Parks_of_Canada" title="National Parks of Canada">National park system</a> and the <i>Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-polls_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-polls-408">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[406]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, Canada has been influenced by <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">British</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_culture" title="French culture">French</a>, and Indigenous cultures and traditions. Through their language, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Native_American_art" title="Native American art">art</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Nations_music" title="First Nations music">music</a>, Indigenous peoples continue to influence the Canadian identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[407]</a></sup> During the 20th century, Canadians with African, Caribbean and Asian nationalities have added to the Canadian identity and its culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TetteyPuplampu2005_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-TetteyPuplampu2005-411">[408]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Canadian_humour" title="Canadian humour">Canadian humour</a> is an integral part of the Canadian identity and is reflected in its <a href="/wiki/Canadian_folklore" title="Canadian folklore">folklore</a>, literature, music, art, and media. The primary characteristics of Canadian humour are irony, parody, and satire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nieguth2015_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nieguth2015-412">[409]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">Symbols</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Canada" title="National symbols of Canada">National symbols of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beaver_sculpture,_Centre_Block.jpg"><img alt="The mother beaver sculpture outside the House of Commons" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2066" data-file-width="2298" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg/200px-Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg/300px-Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg/400px-Beaver_sculpture%2C_Centre_Block.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beaver_sculpture,_Centre_Block.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The mother beaver</i> on the Canadian parliament's <a href="/wiki/Peace_Tower" title="Peace Tower">Peace Tower</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[410]</a></sup> The five flowers on the shield each represent an ethnicity—<a href="/wiki/Tudor_rose" title="Tudor rose">Tudor rose</a>: <a href="/wiki/English_people" title="English people">English</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fleur_de_lis" title="Fleur de lis">Fleur de lis</a>: <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French</a>; <a href="/wiki/Thistle" title="Thistle">thistle</a>: <a href="/wiki/Scottish_people" title="Scottish people">Scottish</a>; <a href="/wiki/Shamrock" title="Shamrock">shamrock</a>: <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">Irish</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Leek" title="Leek">leek</a>: <a href="/wiki/Welsh_people" title="Welsh people">Welsh</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Themes of nature, pioneers, trappers, and traders played an important part in the early development of Canadian symbolism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pioneer_lit_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-pioneer_lit-414">[411]</a></sup> Modern symbols emphasize the country's geography, cold climate, lifestyles and the Canadianization of traditional European and Indigenous symbols.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[412]</a></sup> The use of the <a href="/wiki/Maple_leaf" title="Maple leaf">maple leaf</a> as a Canadian symbol dates to the early 18th century. The maple leaf is depicted on Canada's <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Canada" title="Flag of Canada">current</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Red_Ensign" title="Canadian Red Ensign">previous flags</a>, and on the <a href="/wiki/Arms_of_Canada" title="Arms of Canada">Arms of Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-symbol1_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-symbol1-416">[413]</a></sup> Canada's official tartan, known as the "<a href="/wiki/Regional_tartans_of_Canada" title="Regional tartans of Canada">maple leaf tartan</a>", has four colours that reflect the colours of the maple leaf as it changes through the seasons—green in the <a href="/wiki/Spring_(season)" title="Spring (season)">spring</a>, gold in the early <a href="/wiki/Autumn" title="Autumn">autumn</a>, red at the first <a href="/wiki/Frost" title="Frost">frost</a>, and brown after falling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-torontostar_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-torontostar-417">[414]</a></sup> The Arms of Canada are closely modelled after the <a href="/wiki/Royal_coat_of_arms_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom">royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom</a> with French and distinctive Canadian elements replacing or added to those derived from the British version.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gough2010g_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gough2010g-418">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other prominent symbols include the national motto "<span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/A_mari_usque_ad_mare" title="A mari usque ad mare">A mari usque ad mare</a></i></span>" ("From Sea to Sea"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nischik2008_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nischik2008-419">[416]</a></sup> the sports of <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lacrosse" title="Lacrosse">lacrosse</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Beaver" title="Beaver">beaver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada_goose" title="Canada goose">Canada goose</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_loon" title="Common loon">common loon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canadian_horse" title="Canadian horse">Canadian horse</a>, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the Canadian Rockies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-symbol1_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-symbol1-416">[413]</a></sup> and more recently the <a href="/wiki/Totem_pole" title="Totem pole">totem pole</a> and <a href="/wiki/Inuksuk" title="Inuksuk">Inuksuk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nels_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nels-420">[417]</a></sup> Material items such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadian_beer" title="Canadian beer">Canadian beer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maple_syrup" title="Maple syrup">maple syrup</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuque" title="Tuque">tuques</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canoes" title="Canoes">canoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nanaimo_bar" title="Nanaimo bar">nanaimo bars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butter_tart" title="Butter tart">butter tarts</a> and the Quebec dish of <a href="/wiki/Poutine" title="Poutine">poutine</a> are defined as uniquely Canadian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nels_420-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nels-420">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[418]</a></sup> Canadian coins feature many of these symbols: the loon on the <a href="/wiki/Loonie" title="Loonie">$1 coin</a>, the Arms of Canada on the <a href="/wiki/50-cent_piece_(Canadian_coin)" title="50-cent piece (Canadian coin)">50¢ piece</a>, the beaver on the <a href="/wiki/Nickel_(Canadian_coin)" title="Nickel (Canadian coin)">nickel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Berman2008_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-Berman2008-422">[419]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Penny_(Canadian_coin)" title="Penny (Canadian coin)">penny</a>, removed from circulation in 2013, featured the maple leaf.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[420]</a></sup> An image of the previous monarch, Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Elizabeth II</a>, appears on <a href="/wiki/Canadian_dollar" title="Canadian dollar">$20 bank notes</a>, and on the obverse of all current Canadian coins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Berman2008_422-1"><a href="#cite_note-Berman2008-422">[419]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canadian_literature" title="Canadian literature">Canadian literature</a></div>
<p>Canadian literature is often divided into French- and English-language literatures, which are rooted in the literary traditions of France and Britain, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[421]</a></sup> The earliest Canadian narratives were of travel and exploration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moyles1994_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moyles1994-425">[422]</a></sup> This progressed into three major themes that can be found within historical Canadian literature: nature, frontier life, Canada's position within the world, all three of which tie into the <a href="/wiki/Garrison_mentality" title="Garrison mentality">garrison mentality</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[423]</a></sup> In recent decades, Canada's literature has been strongly influenced by immigrants from around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BRILL2021_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-BRILL2021-427">[424]</a></sup> Since the 1980s, Canada's ethnic and cultural diversity has been openly reflected in its literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dominic2010_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dominic2010-428">[425]</a></sup> By the 1990s, Canadian literature was viewed as some of the world's best.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dominic2010_428-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dominic2010-428">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_writers" title="List of Canadian writers">Canadian authors</a> have accumulated international literary awards,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[426]</a></sup> including novelist, poet, and literary critic <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Atwood" title="Margaret Atwood">Margaret Atwood</a>, who received two <a href="/wiki/Booker_Prize" title="Booker Prize">Booker Prizes</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[427]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel laureate</a> <a href="/wiki/Alice_Munro" title="Alice Munro">Alice Munro</a>, who has been called the best living writer of short stories in English;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[428]</a></sup> and Booker Prize recipient <a href="/wiki/Michael_Ondaatje" title="Michael Ondaatje">Michael Ondaatje</a>, who wrote the novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_English_Patient" title="The English Patient">The English Patient</a></i>, which was adapted as a <a href="/wiki/The_English_Patient_(film)" title="The English Patient (film)">film of the same name</a> that won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Academy Award for Best Picture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[429]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L._M._Montgomery" title="L. M. Montgomery">L. M. Montgomery</a> produced a series of children's novels beginning in 1908 with <i><a href="/wiki/Anne_of_Green_Gables" title="Anne of Green Gables">Anne of Green Gables</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MontgomeryNemo2021_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-MontgomeryNemo2021-433">[430]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Canada" title="Media of Canada">Media of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg/220px-CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg/330px-CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg/440px-CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CBC_Radio_Canada_Chevrolet_Express_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Canadian Broadcasting Corporation">Canadian Broadcasting Corporation</a> (CBC) satellite truck, used for live television broadcasts</div></div></div>
<p>Canada's media is <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">highly autonomous</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_by_country" title="Censorship by country">uncensored</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multicultural_media_in_Canada" title="Multicultural media in Canada">diverse</a> and very regionalized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[431]</a></sup> The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broadcasting_Act_(1991)" title="Broadcasting Act (1991)">Broadcasting Act</a></i> declares "the system should serve to safeguard, enrich and strengthen the cultural, political, social and economic fabric of Canada".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bannerman2020_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bannerman2020-435">[432]</a></sup> Canada has a well-developed media sector, but its cultural output—particularly in <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Canada" title="Cinema of Canada">English films</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Canada" title="Television in Canada">television shows</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_magazines" title="List of Canadian magazines">magazines</a>—is often overshadowed by imports from the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vipond2011y_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vipond2011y-436">[433]</a></sup> As a result, the preservation of a distinctly Canadian culture is supported by federal government programs, laws, and institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Canadian Broadcasting Corporation">Canadian Broadcasting Corporation</a> (CBC), the <a href="/wiki/National_Film_Board_of_Canada" title="National Film Board of Canada">National Film Board of Canada</a> (NFB), and the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Radio-television_and_Telecommunications_Commission" title="Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission">Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission</a> (CRTC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edwardson2008c_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-Edwardson2008c-437">[434]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Canada" title="Mass media in Canada">Canadian mass media</a>, both <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newspapers_of_Canada" title="Newspapers of Canada">print</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_online_media" title="Canadian online media">digital</a> and in both official languages, is largely dominated by a "<a href="/wiki/Media_ownership_in_Canada" title="Media ownership in Canada">handful of corporations</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TarasBakardjievaPannekoek20072_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-TarasBakardjievaPannekoek20072-438">[435]</a></sup> The largest of these corporations is the country's national <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_broadcaster" title="Public broadcaster">public broadcaster</a>, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, which also plays a significant role in producing domestic cultural content, operating <a href="/wiki/CBC_Radio" title="CBC Radio">its own radio</a> and <a href="/wiki/CBC_Television" title="CBC Television">TV</a> networks in both English and French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TarasBakardjievaPannekoek2007_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-TarasBakardjievaPannekoek2007-439">[436]</a></sup> In addition to the CBC, some provincial governments offer their own public educational TV broadcast services as well, such as <a href="/wiki/TVOntario" title="TVOntario">TVOntario</a> and <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A9l%C3%A9-Qu%C3%A9bec" title="Télé-Québec">Télé-Québec</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GlobermanPolicy1983_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-GlobermanPolicy1983-440">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>Non-news media content in Canada, including film and television, is influenced both by local creators as well as by imports from the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia, and France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steven2011_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-Steven2011-441">[438]</a></sup> In an effort to reduce the amount of foreign-made media, government interventions in television broadcasting can include both regulation of content and public financing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[439]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_Canada" title="Taxation in Canada">Canadian tax laws</a> limit foreign competition in magazine advertising.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Krikorian2012_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-Krikorian2012-443">[440]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canadian_art" title="Canadian art">Canadian art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Jack_Pine,_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg"><img alt="Oil on canvas painting of a tree dominating its rocky landscape during a sunset" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1105" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="184" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg/200px-The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg/300px-The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg/400px-The_Jack_Pine%2C_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Jack_Pine,_by_Tom_Thomson.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Jack_Pine" title="The Jack Pine">The Jack Pine</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Tom_Thomson" title="Tom Thomson">Tom Thomson</a>. Oil on canvas, 1916, in the collection of the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Canada" title="National Gallery of Canada">National Gallery of Canada</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Art in Canada is marked by thousands of years of habitation by its indigenous peoples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mullen2020_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mullen2020-444">[441]</a></sup> Historically, the Catholic Church was the primary patron of art in New France and early Canada, especially Quebec,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newlands2000_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-Newlands2000-445">[442]</a></sup> and in later times, artists have combined British, French, Indigenous and American artistic traditions, at times embracing European styles while working to promote nationalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cook_1974_pp._263–283_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cook_1974_pp._263–283-446">[443]</a></sup> The nature of Canadian art reflects these diverse origins, as artists have taken their traditions and adapted these influences to reflect the reality of their lives in Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KasoffJames2013_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-KasoffJames2013-447">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Canadian government has played a role in the development of Canadian culture through the department of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadian_Heritage" title="Canadian Heritage">Canadian Heritage</a>, by giving grants to art galleries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[445]</a></sup> as well as establishing and funding art schools and colleges across the country, and through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canada_Council_for_the_Arts" title="Canada Council for the Arts">Canada Council for the Arts</a> (established in 1957), the national public arts funder, helping artists, art galleries and periodicals, and thus contributing to the development of Canada's cultural works.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BeauregardPaquette2021_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-BeauregardPaquette2021-449">[446]</a></sup> Since the 1950s, works of <a href="/wiki/Inuit_art" title="Inuit art">Inuit art</a> have been given as gifts to foreign dignitaries by the Canadian government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canadian visual art has been dominated by figures such as painter <a href="/wiki/Tom_Thomson" title="Tom Thomson">Tom Thomson</a> and by the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven_(artists)" title="Group of Seven (artists)">Group of Seven</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[448]</a></sup> The Group of Seven were painters with a nationalistic and idealistic focus, who first exhibited their distinctive works in May 1920. Though referred to as having seven members, five artists—<a href="/wiki/Lawren_Harris" title="Lawren Harris">Lawren Harris</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._Y._Jackson" title="A. Y. Jackson">A. Y. Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Lismer" title="Arthur Lismer">Arthur Lismer</a>, <a href="/wiki/J._E._H._MacDonald" title="J. E. H. MacDonald">J. E. H. MacDonald</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Varley" title="Frederick Varley">Frederick Varley</a>—were responsible for articulating the group's ideas. They were joined briefly by <a href="/wiki/Frank_Johnston_(artist)" title="Frank Johnston (artist)">Frank Johnston</a> and by commercial artist <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Carmichael" title="Franklin Carmichael">Franklin Carmichael</a>. <a href="/wiki/A._J._Casson" title="A. J. Casson">A. J. Casson</a> became part of the group in 1926.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[449]</a></sup> Associated with the group was another prominent Canadian artist, <a href="/wiki/Emily_Carr" title="Emily Carr">Emily Carr</a>, known for her landscapes and portrayals of the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Pacific_Northwest_Coast" title="Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast">Indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[450]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Canada" title="Music of Canada">Music of Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:O-Canada-1908.pdf"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1650" data-file-width="1275" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/O-Canada-1908.pdf/page1-170px-O-Canada-1908.pdf.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/O-Canada-1908.pdf/page1-255px-O-Canada-1908.pdf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/O-Canada-1908.pdf/page1-340px-O-Canada-1908.pdf.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:O-Canada-1908.pdf" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Original publication of <a href="/wiki/O_Canada" title="O Canada">O Canada</a>, 1908</div></div></div>
<p>Canadian music reflects a <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Canadian_cultures" title="Music of Canadian cultures">variety of regional scenes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Homan2022_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-Homan2022-454">[451]</a></sup> Canada has developed a vast music infrastructure that includes <a href="/wiki/Church_hall" title="Church hall">church halls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chamber_music" title="Chamber music">chamber halls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_school" title="Music school">conservatories</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academies" title="Academies">academies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Performing_arts_center" title="Performing arts center">performing arts centres</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Record_company" title="Record company">record companies</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radio_stations" title="Radio stations">radio stations</a> and television <a href="/wiki/Music_video" title="Music video">music video</a> channels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-broadcasting-history_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-broadcasting-history-455">[452]</a></sup> Government support programs, such as the Canada Music Fund, assist a wide range of musicians and entrepreneurs who create, produce and market original and diverse Canadian music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HomanCloonanCattermole2017_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-HomanCloonanCattermole2017-456">[453]</a></sup> The Canadian music industry is the sixth-largest in the world, producing internationally renowned <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_composers" title="List of Canadian composers">composers</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Canadian_musicians" title="List of Canadian musicians">musicians</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_bands_from_Canada" title="List of bands from Canada">ensembles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HullHutchison2011a_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-HullHutchison2011a-457">[454]</a></sup> Music broadcasting in the country is regulated by the CRTC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AchesonMaule2009_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-AchesonMaule2009-458">[455]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Academy_of_Recording_Arts_and_Sciences" title="Canadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences">Canadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences</a> presents Canada's music industry awards, the <a href="/wiki/Juno_Award" title="Juno Award">Juno Awards</a>, which were first awarded in 1970.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[456]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Music_Hall_of_Fame" title="Canadian Music Hall of Fame">Canadian Music Hall of Fame</a>, established in 1976, honours Canadian musicians for their lifetime achievements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoffmann2004_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hoffmann2004-460">[457]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Anthems_and_nationalistic_songs_of_Canada" title="Anthems and nationalistic songs of Canada">Patriotic music in Canada</a> dates back over 200 years as a distinct category from British patriotism, preceding Canadian Confederation by over 50 years. The earliest work of patriotic music in Canada, "<a href="/wiki/The_Bold_Canadian" title="The Bold Canadian">The Bold Canadian</a>", was written in 1812.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[458]</a></sup> "<a href="/wiki/The_Maple_Leaf_Forever" title="The Maple Leaf Forever">The Maple Leaf Forever</a>" written in 1866, was a popular patriotic song throughout <a href="/wiki/English_Canada" title="English Canada">English Canada</a> and for many years served as an unofficial national anthem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ref111_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ref111-462">[459]</a></sup> The official national anthem, "<a href="/wiki/O_Canada" title="O Canada">O Canada</a>", was originally commissioned by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lieutenant_governor_of_Quebec" title="Lieutenant governor of Quebec">lieutenant governor of Quebec</a>, <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9odore_Robitaille" title="Théodore Robitaille">Théodore Robitaille</a>, for the 1880 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F%C3%AAte_nationale_du_Qu%C3%A9bec" title="Fête nationale du Québec">St. Jean-Baptiste Day</a> ceremony and was officially adopted in 1980.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[460]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Calixa_Lavall%C3%A9e" title="Calixa Lavallée">Calixa Lavallée</a> wrote the music, which was a setting of a patriotic poem composed by the poet and judge Sir <a href="/wiki/Adolphe-Basile_Routhier" title="Adolphe-Basile Routhier">Adolphe-Basile Routhier</a>. The text was originally only in French before it was adapted into English in 1906.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[461]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_Canada" title="Sports in Canada">Sports in Canada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg/220px-Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg/330px-Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg/440px-Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Canada2010WinterOlympicsOTcelebration.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadian_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team" title="Canadian men's national ice hockey team">Canadian men's national ice hockey team</a> celebrates shortly after winning the gold medal final at the <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics" title="2010 Winter Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/History_of_Canadian_sports" title="History of Canadian sports">roots of organized sports in Canada</a> date back to the 1770s,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[462]</a></sup> culminating in the development and popularization of the major professional games of <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey_in_Canada" title="Ice hockey in Canada">ice hockey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lacrosse_in_Canada" title="Lacrosse in Canada">lacrosse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Curling" title="Curling">curling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball_in_Canada" title="Basketball in Canada">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baseball_in_Canada" title="Baseball in Canada">baseball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soccer_in_Canada" title="Soccer in Canada">association football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canadian_football" title="Canadian football">Canadian football</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[463]</a></sup> Canada's official national sports are ice hockey and lacrosse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[464]</a></sup> Other sports such as <a href="/wiki/Volleyball_in_Canada" title="Volleyball in Canada">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cycling_in_Canada" title="Cycling in Canada">cycling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swimming_(sport)" title="Swimming (sport)">swimming</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bowling" title="Bowling">bowling</a> and the study of <a href="/wiki/Martial_arts" title="Martial arts">martial arts</a> are all widely enjoyed at the youth and amateur levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[465]</a></sup> Great achievements in Canadian sports are recognized by <a href="/wiki/Canada%27s_Sports_Hall_of_Fame" title="Canada's Sports Hall of Fame">Canada's Sports Hall of Fame</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Danilov1997cv_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-Danilov1997cv-469">[466]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Lou_Marsh_Trophy" title="Lou Marsh Trophy">Lou Marsh Trophy</a> is awarded annually to Canada's top athlete by a panel of journalists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zawadzki2001efg_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zawadzki2001efg-470">[467]</a></sup> There are numerous other sport "halls of fame" in Canada, such as the <a href="/wiki/Hockey_Hall_of_Fame" title="Hockey Hall of Fame">Hockey Hall of Fame</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Danilov1997cv_469-1"><a href="#cite_note-Danilov1997cv-469">[466]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada shares several <a href="/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada" title="Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada">major professional sports leagues</a> with the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ButenkoGil-Lafuente2010_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-ButenkoGil-Lafuente2010-471">[468]</a></sup> Canadian teams in these leagues include seven franchises in the <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>, as well as three <a href="/wiki/Soccer_in_Canada#Major_League_Soccer" title="Soccer in Canada">Major League Soccer</a> teams and one team in each of <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a>. Other popular professional competitions include the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Football_League" title="Canadian Football League">Canadian Football League</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Lacrosse_League" title="National Lacrosse League">National Lacrosse League</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Premier_League" title="Canadian Premier League">Canadian Premier League</a>, and the various curling tournaments sanctioned and organized by <a href="/wiki/Curling_Canada" title="Curling Canada">Curling Canada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MorrowWamsley2016_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-MorrowWamsley2016-472">[469]</a></sup>
</p><p>Canada has enjoyed success both <a href="/wiki/Canada_at_the_Winter_Olympics" title="Canada at the Winter Olympics">at the Winter Olympics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canada_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Canada at the Summer Olympics">at the Summer Olympics</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MallonHeijmans2011_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-MallonHeijmans2011-473">[470]</a></sup> though particularly the Winter Games as a "winter sports nation", and has hosted several high-profile international sporting events such as the <a href="/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics" title="1976 Summer Olympics">1976 Summer Olympics</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Howell2009_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-Howell2009-474">[471]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics" title="1988 Winter Olympics">1988 Winter Olympics</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HorneWhannel2016_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-HorneWhannel2016-475">[472]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics" title="2010 Winter Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Development2006_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-Development2006-476">[473]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fromm2006_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fromm2006-477">[474]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2015 FIFA Women's World Cup">2015 FIFA Women's World Cup</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[475]</a></sup> Most recently, Canada hosted the <a href="/wiki/2015_Pan_American_Games" title="2015 Pan American Games">2015 Pan American Games</a> and <a href="/wiki/2015_Parapan_American_Games" title="2015 Parapan American Games">2015 Parapan American Games</a> in Toronto, the former being one of the largest sporting event hosted by the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[476]</a></sup> The country is scheduled to co-host the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2026_World_Cup" title="2026 World Cup">2026 FIFA World Cup</a> alongside Mexico and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[477]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox tright" role="navigation">
<ul>
